title: AS13_TEC
question_text: When the CDR and LMP are in the undocked lunar module or on the lunar surface, their speaker designations will be suffixed by either LM or EVA to indicate their status (e.g., CDR-EVA or LMP-LM). Voice calls during this mission were assigned in accordance with the following station operating procedures: "For all phases when only the CSM is manned, the AS-508 call sign will be Apollo 13. When both vehicles are manned, the call sign will be Odyssey for the CSM and Aquarius for the LM.
answer_text: The call signs for the CDR and LMP during lunar surface operations will be the individual crew's first names."

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: And, Houston, what's the story on engine 5?

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: 13, Houston. I have your Z torquing angles. You ready?

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Houston, how do you read 13?

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Would it be okay if 1 crank up the FM . . . . . . ?

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Would it be okay, Joe, if we crank up the FM after we leave Honeysuckle here?

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: What TV was that? Okay, 13 - - 00 0l 04 55 LMP Okay, Joe. I just wanted to put on the TV switch at Honeysuckle to tune her up there.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: 13, Houston. Did you copy your AOS time?

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: And we're just coming up on Baja, and I've got the TV on. Do you want it?

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: (Laughter) How do you like it?

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Joe, we had a dropout of signal there about midway or about a fifth of the start of your pad, and Fred didn't get it. We'd like you to start over again Could you please?

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Sure thing. You want the whole thing?

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Did you notice? 002:46:42 CDR Okay. On my trusty watch, I had about 3-3/4 seconds long. 002:46:49 CC Okay. Copy that. 002:48:34 CC Apollo 13, Houston. 002:48:38 CDR Roger, Houston; 13 here. 002:48:39 CC Okay.
answer_text: We have the S-IVB maneuver to SEP attitude commencing at 2 plus 56 plus 37. Duration of the maneuver: 4 minutes. SEP time, 3 plus 06 plus 37.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: We are going to have to press on here, Joe, so we are back inside. 003:49:00 CC Okay. Thanks a lot. 003:54:04 LMP Okay. How's that picture looking back outside now, Joe?
answer_text: Getting ready for LM extraction. 003:54:13 CC Okay. That looks pretty good, Fred. 003:54:14 CDR Houston, this 13. Do we have a GO for pyro arm? 003:54:20 CC 13, Houston.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Can you wait, or do you want to do it right now? 004:05:09 CC We can wait if you want us to, Jim. 004:05:11 CDR Why don't you wait just a little bit. 004:05:13 CC Okay. 004:06:02 CMP Joe, did they ever get an idea of what that - the TD and E fuel was? 004:06:09 CC Jack, they're not willing to pin it down to a specific number right now because they say the tanks will warm up later on and the apparent consumption will go down. But it was nominal. 004:06:20 CMP Okay. 004:08:26 CMP Okay, Houston. We have the S-IVB in sight.
answer_text: You are G0 to maneuver the S-IVB. 004:08:31 CC Houston, Roger that. 004:09:04 CMP Try to give you a - Houston, we're going to try to give you a shot of the S-IVB with the TV out window number 3. 004:09:11 CC Okay. Real good, Jack. Our S-band signal strength has been fluctuating.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Does it seem to be going all right up there in the AUTO TRACK mode? 004:09:24 LMP Yes. Right now; yes, it's dropped off to about the 70-percent point, Joe , and it was before up about 85. 004:09:34 CC Okay. 004:09:54 CDR And, Houston, do you have a TV picture? 004:09:57 CC Not at the moment, Jim. We had a garbled one there for a few seconds and we don't have one at this moment. 004:10:05 CDR Okay.
answer_text: I can see the S-IVB now out the hatch window and it's - - 004:10:11 CC Okay, Jim. Suddendy we have a very good picture. 004:10:13 CDR Okay. 004:10:50 CDR And, Houston, I can see the gold shroud around the I0, and it looks that it's all intact. 004:10:56 CC Roger, Jim. We copy that.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: How much longer would you like the television? 004:20:10 CC Stand by on that. We'll get a word. 004:20:21 CC Okay, 13, this is Houston. You can turn the TV off anytime youre ready.
answer_text: Weve enjoyed the show. 004:20:40 CC 13, Houston. Before you secure the TV, wed like to know whether that was maximum zoom, just for information- 004:20:48 LMP Thats affirm. Jim had it in MAX zoom. 004:20:51 CC Okay.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Do you want to dump waste water down to 25 percent. Is that right? 006:59:33 CC That's affirm. 006:59:34 CMP Okay, in work. 006:59:35 CC Okay. 007:00:18 CMP Do you know we're also purging fuel cells O2 now. 007:00:21 CC Okay, Jack. 007:09:31 CMP Okay, Houston. The fuel cell purge and waste water dump are complete. 007:09:38 CC Roger, Apollo 13.
answer_text: And this is your relief CAP COMM shift on now. 007:09:49 CDR Well, good evening, Vance. 007:09:53 CMP Boy, you sure made it back fast. 007:09:55 CC Yes. You guys had a beautiful launch, there. Really nice. 007:10:07 CMP Could you follow it all the way up, Vance? 007:10:11 CC No, I didn't see staging.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Over. 007:33:11 CDR Go ahead. 007:33:12 CC Jim, we'd like to verify that the high gain is secured, that the S-BAND antenna is on OMNI, and OMNI B should be the right antenna. Over. 007:33:27 CDR Okay. You want the high gain secured and you want the OMNI on OMNI Charlie, huh?
answer_text: Or Baker? 007:33:35 CC That's affirm. And this'll be maintained in the PTC. 007:33:39 CDR Okay. 007:33:50 CC And the high gain angles for stowage - or for stowing - are pitch minus 52, yaw 270. 007:39:21 CDR Houston, Apollo 13. 007:39:24 CC Roger. Go ahead. 007:39:26 CDR Stand by for another Earth weather picture.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: How do you read? 007:54:48 LMP Okay. And do you have any estimate, Vance, on how long we'll be charging battery B? 007:55:01 CC Stand by 1, Fred. 007:55:21 CC Apollo 13, Houston. 007:55:24 CDR Go ahead. 007:55:26 CC We'll be charging for 4-1/2 to 5 hours yet, Jim. 007:55:32 CDR Roger. 008:02:33 CC Apollo 13, Houston. 008:02:36 LMP Go ahead. 008:02:39 CC Fred, recommend that, when your window comes around facing the Earth again, that you catch another one of those pictures, and at the same time, you should probably start PTC again. We might have sent a confusing bit of info up to you.
answer_text: The "disable two quads" only applies to an early step in the procedure. We didn't mean that for the latter part of the procedure where we have the statement "enable all jets." Over. 008:03:15 LMP Okay. 008:07:33 CMP Houston, Apollo 13. 008:07:43 CC Apollo 13, Houston. Go ahead. 008:07:46 CMP Vance, Fred said that you had some more informa- tion about PTC and a different way of establishing it or something, huh? 008:07:55 CC Roger, Referring to the procedure on G/8-2, if you have that open, I'll tell you what we had to give you. 008:08:11 CMP Okay.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: The second extra question is for you, Jim, and it says, "Comparing this flight with your ride on Apollo 8, were there any significant differences in the powered flight environment?" 023:25:35 CDR Okay. We'll describe a comparison with 8 and 13 as far as powered flight goes. 023:25:41 CC Roger. And the last additional question is what did the ORDEAL ball look like during TLI?
answer_text: As you know, we passed you an update to that setting, and we'd like to know whether it was riding right on zero or what during the burn. Over. 023:26:00 CDR Okay. Will do.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: When you get all done, I'll - I'll make a quick check to see if the booster people have any - any additional questions. You skipped number 8, Jim; could you go back to that for a second? 025:23:34 CDR Okay, stand by. 025:23:54 CDR Our only comment there, Joe, was that the burn on TLI, to our knowledge, was about 3-3/4 second longer than had been predicted and that was the only thing that we really noticed; otherwise, looked like PI [?] was nominal at cut-off. 025:24:11 CC Okay, understand. 025:24:23 CDR Okay, on comparing the flight of 13 to Apollo 8, lift-off was about the same amount of vibration as I noticed on 8, but at the beginning of the flight, there was less of the sideways motion than we experienced on Apollo 8. The S-IC separa- tion felt more violent on 13 than it did on 8, maybe that's because I was in a different seat, I don't know.
answer_text: But there was about three sharp transients of the cut-off and a couple of big bangs where we were thrown backwards longitudinally on our straps before the S-II went off. And the S-II was, of course, just as smooth on 13 as 8 except for the number 5 engine. And we did not experience the vibration that we experienced on 8 towards the end of the S-II burn.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Here it comes. 030:13:04 CC Okay. 030:13:53 CC Okay. Jack. It's coming in, and it's right in the center of our screen. 030:14:00 CMP Okay, Vance. 030:14:04 LMP Can you - Think you could guess what that might be, Vance?
answer_text: Better than Charlie? 030:14:14 CC I don't want to start flipping coins at this point. 030:14:21 CMP Okay, Vance. We're pointed just a little ways off from looking directly at the Moon. Jim is holding the camera through window 3.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Could you adjust it so that you're coming in continuously all the time? 030:31:08 CDR Okay. Stand by 1. 030:31:17 CDR 1, 2, 3, 4, 5. How's that, Vance? 030:31:21 CC Okay.
answer_text: That's better. 030:32:04 CMP Vance, how do you read the CMP on VOX? 030:32:07 CC Jack, read you loud and clear. 030:32:10 CMP Okay. Fine. 030:32:21 CDR We show minus 8-1/2 minutes. 030:32:25 CC Roger. Houston copies. 01 06 32 44 SC Close 030:33:00 LMP Is that too close, Vance, or can you make out the SPS engine panel now? 030:33:06 CC We can see your fuel and oxidizer gages and hydrogen/oxygen gages at the top of the picture and the PUGS, but it isn't coming in in focus too well.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Check MTVC. 030:35:54 LMP MTVC checked. Okay. 030:35:56 LMP Okay. 030:35:57 LMP THC - - 030:35:58 LMP ... C - - 030:35:59 LMP - - TRIM returns to NEUTRAL. 030:36:03 LMP Clockwise on the translation controller. ^ 030:36:05 LMP Mine?
answer_text: No MTVC. 030:36:06 LMP No MTVC. Okay. 030:36:07 LMP Starting ... 030:36:08 LMP Okay. 030:36:09 LMP Okay. 01 06 36 10 IMP Go ahead. 030:36:11 LMP PITCH 2, START. 030:36:12 LMP Good. 030:36:13 LMP YAW 2, START. 030:36:14 LMP Okay. Both good. 030:36:15 LMP Good.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: MAX trim up to zero. 030:36:30 LMP Good. No MTVC. 030:36:31 LMP No MTVC. 030:36:33 LMP Okay. 030:36:34 LMP BMAGs MODE, RATE 2. 030:36:36 LMP ROTATIONAL HAND CONTROL POWER, two, NORMAL, AC/DC. 030:36:38 LMP AC/DC. 030:36:39 LMP RATE 2, MAIN A/MAIN B. 030:36:41 LMP B. 030:36:42 LMP Okay. BMAGs, you got three, RATE 2?
answer_text: Okay, we'll proceed for final trim. 030:36:54 LMP MAG's where we are. 030:36:55 LMP Okay. BMAG MODEs, three, ATT l/RATE 2. 030:36:58 LMP ATT l/RATE 2. 030:36:59 LMP ... ENTER.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: What I'm going to do is give you a shot of Fred. 030:44:23 LMP If we can get all the wiring out of the way. 030:44:27 LMP The big problem here is, when you move the TV around, this wire follows you like a snake here. 030:44:35 LMP Yes, we have Fred now. Looks like he has a lariat there, getting ready to rope the checklist. 030:44:47 LMP That's only half of it. We have most of it hidden away.
answer_text: It's been pretty interesting doing all the camera work here to get a little extra training running the TV here, hopefully for when we get on the ground at Fra Mauro. The monitor does make it pretty easy though. 030:45:12 LMP Right. That's a real advantage in the cockpit.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: We - We heard you go through the checklist. But, I guess right now, basically, you probably have all the switches back in position and you're in the mode to con- tinue on with - Okay. What does the flight plans say?
answer_text: You're going to be doing cislunar naviga- tion. So, Jack you're going to be down in the LEB. Is that correct? 030:50:12 LMP That's right, Vance.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: And cross out the penned-in "E4" below that. 033:06:02 CMP Okay, go ahead. 033:06:04 CC Okay, and the next page, 29, right-hand side near the top, cross out "Photo target 13, north at 5.6, 250," et cetera, all of that line. And cross out beneath that the penned-in "E5 slash 6." 033:06:27 CMP All right. 033:06:29 CC Going to page 30, next, left-hand side. 033:06:45 CMP Go ahead. 033:06:47 CC At the top at 127:01, cross out "Visual target 9 on track, 180 degrees, plus 0.47," and cross out the penned-in "Ell" beneath that. 033:07:08 CMP Okay. 033:07:10 CC Going down to 127:11, cross out "Verify DSE ON." Beneath that a ways, cross out "127:14:20, start visual observations of Fra Mauro." 033:07:34 CMP All right. 033:07:36 CC Beneath that, cross out "Continue visual observa- tions," and cross out "Stop observations." And beneath that, cross out "Photo target 56 on track f:8, 250, infinity, 5," et cetera, to the end of that line. Cross out the "5.6" beneath that and the penned-in "El5." 033:08:12 CMP Okay. 033:08:14 CC Over in the margin, to the left of all that, make a comment: "Delete visual only." 033:08:38 CMP Where was that, Vance?
answer_text: I didn't get that last one. 033:08:42 CC Okay. That's still on page 30, on the left-hand side. In the time - in the margin at the left where you have times, just pen in beneath the "127:10" the following: "Delete visual only." That's only a comment. 033:09:04 CMP Okay.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: After the P52 realine at 49 hours, if time permits we would like the crew to investigate while in PTC if there is a roll angle in which the comet can be observed for photos. If there is, record the optimum roll angle for possible photography, prior to reinitiating PTC at 56:30 or so, whenever the guys are done in the LM, use P52 planet option, and the following half-unit vectors for tracking Comet Bennett at about 49:46. Are you ready to copy half-unit vectors?
answer_text: Over. 048:01:05 CMP Okay. Go ahead, Joe. 048:01:07 CC Okay. Rl plus 0.34202, minus 0.07374, R^ plus 0.35719.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: When we went to tank 1 AUTO, tank 2 OFF; we found that the heater cycle had a tank 1 pressure of about 233 psi, which is well above the caution and warning limit, and if we go to that configuration for sleep, we'll keep from getting CAUTION AND WARNING lights during the sleep cycle. Okay. In order to do that comfortably, we want to spend the rest of the day using more H2 out of tank number 2, so as to get an unbalance in favor of tank 1, so at the end of the sleep cycle it'll all come out even.
answer_text: And that' s why we have you in tank 1 OFF, tank 2 AUTO, now. We expect to get about a 3-percent unbalance over the next 10 hours; and prior to sleep, we'll call you to reverse the configuration again. Now the only disadvantage here is that, during the day, you will probably get a few CAUTION AND WARNINGS, and we just figured it would be better to get them now than while you were sacked out.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: You're loud and clear now. INCO tells me he's having a little problem at Goldstone and wants me to stand by for a minute. 050:31:02 LMP Okay. How do you read now, Joe?
answer_text: I'm going from OMNI C to D now. 050:31:06 CC You're still loud and clear on - on D, Fred. Stand by 1. 050:31:14 LMP Okay. I'll Put her back to OMNI B if you all want to take command again? 050:31:49 LMP And the Iast thing we heard, Joe, was that the SUPERCRIT should be reading about 710 psi. 050:31:56 CC Okay.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: How do you read? 050:40:22 CC 13, Houston. Loud and clear. What OMNI you on now? 050:40:28 LMP I'm going to stay OMNI B, if you all want to take command back and you can let INCO jockey them around between B and D.
answer_text: And how many steps we got, so I know whether to write big or small here, Joe? 050:40:41 CC Okay. We got steps 6 through 12, but step 7 is the same size as 6, and 8 through 12 are short. They're only one line each. 050:40:53 LMP Okay. 050:40:54 CC Okay.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Circuit breaker panel 11, AC BUS B, HELIUM PQGS DISPLAY, CLOSED. Main - Circuit breaker panel 11, AC BUS B, NUMERIC LIGHTING, CLOSED. CD panel 11, AC BUS - Is that AC BUS B?
answer_text: BUS TIE INVERTER 1, CLOSED? 050:45:51 CC That's affirmative. 050:45:53 LMP And CB - CB EPS INVERTER 1, panel 11, CLOSED. CB panel 16, INSTRUMENT SIGNAL SENSOR, CLOSED. INVERTER 1, SELECT.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Say again? 052:08:37 CDR I said I'd like to invite you to the horse races with me. 052:08:41 CC Right. We'll - We'll send EECOMM. 052:16:55 LMP Well, it's time for a little grits again here, Vance. 052:17:01 CC Understand. Some grits, huh?
answer_text: Chow. Bon apetit. 052:45:20 CC Apollo 13, Houston. 052:45:25 CDR Go ahead, Houston. 052:45:27 CC Roger. Just expect that same CAUTION AND WARNING to come on again.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: How are you reading me now, Jim? 052:46:33 CDR Houston, Apollo 13. 052:46:36 CC 13, Houston. How do you read now? 052:46:41 CDR Okay. Read you good now.
answer_text: Seems like we've had a little trouble with the COMM today. 052:46:46 CC Yes. I guess it's partly because you are further out. We just wanted to tell you that you were going to get that CAUTION WARNING that you just got. 052:46:58 CDR Right.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: We'd like to move up the waste water dump and maybe the 02 fuel cell purge a little bit early, if we could. 053:23:51 CC Okay, stand by. 053:26:30 CC Apollo 13, Houston. 053:26:35 CDR Go ahead, Houston. 053:26:37 CC Jim, you're clear to go on into the LM, and just advise though that the TV time is still fixed at 55 hours, and - so we'll be standing by to support your entry and we'll get back with you on a minute - in a minute on the 02 fuel cell purge and the waste water dump. 053:26:59 CDR Okay. Sounds good. 053:27:02 CC And also request your LM/CM DELTA-P which was on the flight plan for 53 hours. What did you vent it down to?
answer_text: Over. 053:27:16 CDR We have 1.7 now. We vented it down to that figure. 053:27:20 CC Okay, you vented down to 1.7, and what did it start at? 053:27:28 CDR It was about 1.1, Vance. 053:27:31 CC Roger, copy. 053:34:32 LMP Houston, 13. 053:34:35 CC Go ahead, 13. 053:34:40 LMP What do you read for suit pressure down there? 053:34:53 CC We're reading 4.3, Fred. 053:34:59 LMP Okay. 053:38:58 CDR Houston, 13. 053:39:03 CC Go ahead, Apollo 13. 053:39:07 CDR We'd like another confirmation, when we closed the tunnel vent valve back to LM/CM DELTA-P, we were reading about 1.7 - 1.75, and it slowly went up now to about - oh, I'd say a little less than 2.2. Seems to be holding there - Is there a lag in the gaging system? 053:39:33 CC Okay.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Do you want me to back out of this in reverse at least as far as getting this part of it powered down? 054:52:36 CC Stand by 1. 054:52:56 CC Fred, this is Houston. Go ahead and back out of this little test and proceed. 054:53:04 LMP Roger. 054:59:01 CMP Okay. We're back on CSM power.
answer_text: The time was 54 hours 58 minutes 50 seconds. 054:59:10 CC Roger, Jack. 54:58:50. Thank you. 054:59:26 CMP Okay, Houston, we'll try to pick you up on the high gain. 054:59:32 CC Roger. 055:00:08 CC And, 13, we're ready on the TV when you are. 055:00:19 CDR This is 13. Say again, Houston. 055:00:23 CC 13, we're ready on the TV when you are.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Can you - can you read the high gain now? 055:05:24 CC Affirmative, Jack. We've got you on a high gain and it appears to us that we're in wide beam - wide beam width. 055:05:32 CMP Yes. We can't get it to come down to narrow.
answer_text: We tried to switch to AUTO track or REACQ, and it - yaw drives around from 270 to 0. And pitch goes from about 6 degrees around to 90. I'm trying - we're fitting it manual now at the angles that you gave us, and I'll try and get you in medium and narrow beam widths picking it up manually here. 055:06:06 CC Roger, Jack.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Can you give us, maybe, a slight maneuver? 055:09:09 CC Jack, we'd like you to check two high gain circuit breakers down in panel 25. Check your high gain group 2 and your high gain in the flight bus. Over. 055:09:19 CMP Okay.
answer_text: Okay, Jack, they're both IN. 055:09:27 CC Roger. 055:10:43 CC 13, we've got an attitude suggestion for you. We suggest that you go to roll 285 and try pitch 90 and yaw 0. Over. 055:10:57 CMP Okay. 055:14:00 CDR Okay, Houston; Apollo 13.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Do I - l have the DAP right now 'wide deadband. Do you want me to begin setting up nar deadband and nulling the rates to start PTC a- 055:26:47 CC Stand by, Jack. 055:27:31 LMP What I'm fishing out now, Jack, is another new piece of hardware that we are taking along this time as a result of some comments made on the Apollo 12 flight. 055:27:52 CDR What Fred is opening up - is a drink bag that we place inside of our neckring that will allow us to drink while we are on the lunar surface. They - Pete and Al - did not have that on Apollo 12 and they, consequently, got very thirsty.
answer_text: But we hope to alleviate that situation by having our own little bag of water which, with very little effort, we can have a sip or two while we are looking around and doing our geology work. 055:28:33 LMP So if you hear any funny noises, it is just probably the drink bag. 055:28:50 CDR Fred, the bag's empty. 055:29:16 CDR Fred is now looking through our optical device. It's an instrument in which to aline our platform, and Fred is now looking into it just to see what kind of an outside picture he might be able to get. We might be able to use a TV camera to look through our optical instrument to the outside of the command module.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Did you get that? 056:09:04 CC 02 QUANTITY number 2 is zero. 056:09:07 CDR That's AC, okay. Yes, that's good AC and it looks to me, looking out the hatch, that we are venting something. We are venting something out into the - into space. 056:09:22 CC Roger.
answer_text: We copy your venting. 056:09:29 CDR It's a gas of some sort. 056:09:49 LMP Okay. Fuel cell 1, you just wanted it off the line now. Jack, is that right? 056:09:52 CC We just wanted you to open the circuit on fuel cell 1. 056:09:58 LMP Okay.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Do you read? 056:13:20 LMP Yes. We got it. 056:13:21 CDR Affirm. 056:13:22 CC Okay. Can you tell us anything about the venting, where it is coming from, what window you see it at. 056:13:30 LMP It's coming out of window 1, right now, Jack, and could you give me the thrusters again? 056:13:35 CC Okay, the thrusters - - 056:13:37 LMP What buses? 056:13:38 CC We'd like - on MAIN A, we'd like Charlie 1, 2, 3, and 4.
answer_text: Also Bravo 3 and 4 on MAIN A. 056:13:52 LMP Okay. Got it. 056:14:42 CC 13, we need OMNI Bravo. 056:14:46 LMP 0MMI Bravo. 056:16:08 CC Okay, 13; this is Houston. We'd like you to to your G&C checklist, the pink pages, 1-5.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Can you pick up any jets firing? 056:22:54 CC Stand by. What direction are your rates in. Jack? 056:23:06 CMP It's negative pitch and negative roll. 056:23:12 CC Roger. 056:24:42 CC 13, Houston.
answer_text: We need to get some more instrumentation up. We'd like you to put INVERTER 1 on both AC BUSES. Over. 056:24:53 LMP Okay.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Close the REAC valve on fuel cell 3. 056:57:48 LMP Okay. I'll go to the SSR page. Do you want me to go through that whole smash for fuel cell shut- down?
answer_text: Is that correct? 056:57:57 CC Stand by. 056:58:24 CC Okay, 13. We want you to turn the inline heaters off on fuel cell 1. Then we want you to go through the fuel cell shutdown procedure on fuel cell 3.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Do you want some readings from the systems test meter regarding fuel cells? 057:09:45 CC Stand by 1 on that. Jack. Let me ask the EEC0M. 057:09:46 CMP We've got some incompatibilities here. 057:10:03 CC Okay, 13.
answer_text: We'd like to have you give us those systems test readings on fuel cell 1 and 3, please. 057:10:11 CDR Okay. 1 and 3 coming up. 057:10:14 LMP Okay. Jack, 1-A is reading. Lower scale, 0; 1-B is reading 3.45.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Did you copy? 057:15:24 CMP Okay. Well, what bus configuration - What main bus do you want powered? 057:15:36 CC Okay, Jack. We want you to leave the bus configuration as it is.
answer_text: Fuel cell 2 on MAIN A, and we need OMNI Bravo. 057:15:52 CMP Okay, Jack. We're proceeding on the shutdown procedure for fuel cell 1. 057:16:35 CC And, 13, Houston. We'd like you to isolate the REPRESS package, please. 057:16:42 CMP Okay. 057:16:43 CDR Isolate the REPRESS package.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Did you copy that? Is - does GUIDO want anything, a VERB 74 or anything done with the CMC? 057:21:06 CC Stand by. 057:21:54 CC 13, Houston. We're ready with a VERB 74 now, please. 057:22:05 CMP Coming down at you. 057:23:54 CMP Okay, Jack.
answer_text: It looks like 02 tank 1 pressure is just a hair over 200. 057:24:02 CC We confirm that here and the temperature also confirms it. 057:24:09 CMP Okay. Does it look like it's still going down? 057:24:12 CC It's slowly going to zero, and we're starting to think about the LM lifeboat. 057:24:20 CMP Yes. That's what we're thinking about, too.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Do you want me to do that? Okay. We just tried it and quad Alfa and Charlie barber poles are showing. 057:33:01 CC Stand by, Jim. 057:33:03 CMP Okay, Jack.
answer_text: That's the sec - secondary propellant barber poles on Alfa and Charlie. 057:34:47 CC 13, Houston. It won't do any good to try to power the propellant valves on A and C, so we want you to disable the AUTO on RCS Charlie. And we have a procedure for getting power from the LM we'd like you to copy down. 057:35:08 CMP Okay. 057:35:09 CDR Stand by, Jack. 057:35:11 CMP That sounds like good news. 02 09 36 05 IMP Okay, Jack.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Do step 3. Is that correct? 057:43:59 CC That's affirmative, Jim. 057:44:03 CDR Activation 11, omit step 1, do the rest. Is that correct? 057:44:06 CC That's affirmative. 057:44:12 CDR Do Activation 1 and Activation 13, step 1. 057:44:14 CC That's all correct. 057:44:25 CMP Okay, Jack.
answer_text: Pressure in tank 1 is approaching 100 psi. What's going to be the symptoms of this fuel cell starting to drop off? 057:44:51 CC Stand by. Jack.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Coarse aline? 058:00:57 CDR Do it right. Take your time. 058:01:32 CC And, Aquarius, Houston. We'd like you to, on your alinement, can you continue right on through the fine aline Activation 31?
answer_text: Go right on through step 7. Over. 058:01:45 LMP Okay. You want to go on 31 through step number 7, Jack. 058:01:50 CC That's affirmative.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: VERB 41, NOUN 20. Okay. You want plus?
answer_text: Plus or minus? Plus 302.43? Is that right? 058:03:12 LMP Okay.

title: AS13_TEC
answer_text: ENTER. Okay. 058:03:53 CC Odyssey, Houston - - 02 10 03 54 CDR 058:03:55 CC - - your battery A on. 058:03:59 CMP Battery A on now. 058:04:01 CC Go ahead, Aquarius. 058:04:03 CDR Houston. Okay.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: What is it? What's that? 58? 58:07? 058:08:15 CMP 58 what? 058:09:16 CDR Houston, Aquarius. 058:09:18 CC Go ahead, Aquarius. 058:09:23 CDR Here are the gimbal angles. Command module, 356.69, 163.42, 346.67.
answer_text: Aquarius is 302.26, 345.92, 011.79. Over. 058:09:47 CC Okay, Jim. I got command module 356.65, 163.42, 346.67.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Did you copy down about the CMC IMU? 058:14:52 CMP Yes, Jack. I read it back twice to you. Command reset, which I've done.
answer_text: I'm about to power down the IMU, power down the CMC, turn the IMU heaters off, leave BAT A on. 058:15:07 CC That's affirm. Thank you. 058:15:11 CMP Okay. I just got a MASTER ALARM and MAIN BUS A UNDERV0LT.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Do you want me to proceed by the SCS powerdown checklist? I did not copy the SCS items you wanted me to power down. 058:21:32 CC Okay, Odyssey. We want to go SCS ELECTRONICS POWER, OFF. 058:21:39 CMP Okay.
answer_text: It's done. 058:21:41 CC FDAI P0WER/GPI, OFF. AUTO jet SELECT, 16 - - 058:21:47 CMP That's done. 058:21:48 CC - - OFF. And all your ROTATIONAL CONTROL POWER, OFF. 058:21:52 CMP It's done.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: How far are you from RCS power up - RCS pressurization? 058:27:45 LMP Okay, Jack. I'm right up to where it's MASTER ARM, ON; RCS, FIRE; - - 02 10 27 49 MS 058:27:50 LMP - - both LOGIC POWERs out ... goes into normal circuit-breaker. ... Do you want A in and then I'll fire them? 058:27:59 CC Okay, 13.
answer_text: You're both talking at once. One at a time, please. 058:28:10 CMP Okay. Who's first? 058:28:11 CC Close LOGIC POWER A and B, Fred, and pressurize RCS. 058:28:17 LMP Okay. 058:28:24 CC Go ahead, Odyssey. 058:28:29 CMP Okay.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: I'm going to try to do the best I can. I've got a one-attitude reference I'm going to fly according to the lunar terminator. 058:28:37 CC Roger, Jack. Just maintain attitude. 058:29:04 CMP What am I doing?
answer_text: I can't do that, anyway. Let's see, cross feed. Nope.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: How do you read? 058:31:56 CC Okay, Jim. This is Houston. We want you to load the DAP with 30120. 058:32:06 CDR Load the DAP with 30120.
answer_text: Complete. 058:32:16 LMP Okay. We need to change that CSM weight. 058:32:25 CC Okay, Aquarius. Your CSM weight is 63400. 058:32:51 CDR And Jack's alive to take control the LM to stay away from gimbal lock.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: What we want you to do is close the reactants valve on fuel cell 2. Power down your inverters. Power down your battery relay bus.
answer_text: Battery ties, off, and pull your entry circuit breakers, entry battery circuit breakers A, B, and C. 058:37:15 CMP Check the control, and make sure we don't go to gimbal lock, Fred. 058:37:21 CMP Okay, Jack; understand. Close REAC valve circuit breakers in fuel cell 2. Power down inverters.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: What page is the, do we write the gyro torquing angles on there, Jack? 058:44:17 CC Standby. 058:44:18 LMP Okay. We're there now, Jim. Jim's got it.
answer_text: Go ahead with the gyro torquing angles. 058:44:24 CC Okay. We'd like you to proceed with the fine aline and your gyro torquing angles are X plus 003.30, Y plus 024.80, Z minus 015.10. Over. 058:44:48 CDR Okay.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Jim's going to be in trouble in our present attitude out his side. The Sun's there. 058:48:25 CDR Wait 1. 058:48:29 LMP What have you got? How much you got left in battery A?
answer_text: Okay. I wish I knew what the hell they were thinking right not ... - - 058:48:51 CDR They're talking about powering down and doing a P51 here? 058:48:57 LMP No. They were just thinking about P52 - - 058:49:00 CC Aquarius, Houston.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Negative on the P51. We want to stay just like we are, but we'd like to be able to correlate what you're doing with some simulator work we're going to crank up. And so if you can give us information as to what stars you can see out the window, we can make that correlation. 058:49:22 CDR Would you say one more time?
answer_text: Give me the top two. The top two. 058:49:33 CC Jim, what we want you to do is go with your cur- rent fine aline and disregard the P51. What we're attempting to do is to crank up some LMS simulations to correlate what we can get out your window with what we can get out the LMS window to see if that will help us any.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: How do you read? 058:54:05 CC Reading you 5 square, Jim. Go ahead. 058:54:09 CDR Okay. I'm looking out of Fred's window.
answer_text: I see a lot of particles out there, but a lot of that stuff is still drifting away from us, so a lot of it is flashing in the local vicinity, and I don't recognize any constellations right now, in this particular attitude. 058:54:34 CC Okay, Jim. If that status changes, please let us know. 058:54:41 CDR Roger. We're continuing to drift.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Do you - you fight roll by using the TTCA left right. That's what you need to play with. 059:06:04 CDR Okay. We'll try that.
answer_text: Let me get around though. Let's roll. Let it roll all the way. 059:06:12 LMP Yes, you can't let it roll all the way. 059:06:13 CDR I know.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: That's at 79, and what are we at now? About - do we - do we - do we even know any better computer time, do we? 059:06:57 CDR No. 059:07:00 LMP Hey, Jack. Do you still have a mission timer?
answer_text: You don't? Okay. 059:07:07 CDR I'll tell you what. Let's ask - let's ask Houston to give us a mission timer, computer time.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Where are those bags for weighing water in the PLSS? 059:09:02 LMP Why? 059:09:03 CDR We're going to fill up command module water. We'll ... 059:09:09 LMP Hell, do you need a QD *** Jim. No way to get ours in there.
answer_text: I don't think. 059:09:37 LMP Hey, Jim. 059:09:44 CDR I wonder if one of our water ... jet is. Okay, let's control - What else can we fill up there? 059:10:00 CC Aquarius, Houston. 059:10:02 LMP We're not - we're not going to - - 059:10:03 CC We're not going to be able to up link your time because of the IU, and we have a frequency problem there. But what I'd like to do is give you a time to set up on your mission timer and give you a mark and then you can put it into the DSKY from there.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Over. 059:10:25 CDR Okay. Standby. 059:10:27 LMP Wait a minute. Why do we need a mission timer right now, anyway?
answer_text: I mean, that bad, they'd tell us. 059:10:32 CDR Well, I'd rather have a timer going so that we - what are we going to put in the DSKY? Should we shut down the mission timer? 059:10:37 LMP Is that what you want to do? 059:10:38 CDR Yes. Hey, OMNI. 059:10:43 LMP Great. 059:10:47 CDR Switch them.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: What do you think? 059:41:36 CC Stand by 1. 059:41:42 CDR Better still so ws won't freeze up our urine dump. 059:41:48 CC Roger. That sounds like a good plan, Jim. Why don't you go ahead with that one? 059:42:59 CC Okay, Aquarius.
answer_text: And down here we're getting regrouped, trying to work on your control modes and trying to set up something for PTC and taking a look at consumables as opposed to flight plan, and so forth, and as soon as we get all that in- formation, we'll pass it up to you. We also have the 14 backup crew over in the simulators looking at dock burns and also trying to see what kind of alinement procedures they can come up with for looking at stars out the window. So if you ever are able to see any stars out there and think you can do an alinement out the window, why let us know. 059:43:40 CDR Okay.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: What we're really trying to do, Jim, is see if we can do a COAS aline so we can power down the platform. 059:45:23 CDR That is Aquarius. We're getting an awful lot of static on the uplink now, and we're not reading you at all. 059:45:39 CDR I have good signal strength and I'm on AFT OMNI. 059:45:51 CC How do you read now, Aquarius? 059:47:06 CC Hey, Jim, do you suppose that you could orient the LM so that the service module would be between you and the Sun? I believe you could see - recognize constellations out your front windows then. 059:47:47 CC Aquarius, Houston.
answer_text: Radio check. 059:48:15 CDR Okay, Jack. How do you read now? 059:48:17 CC Okay. Hearing you 5 square now, Jim.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: How do you read? 059:59:09 CC Hello there, Aquarius. Loud and clear. How do you read me? 059:59:14 CDR There's an awful lot of background - - 059:59:16 LMP We get a lot of background static, Jack.
answer_text: You're down in the mud. You having a ground problem? 059:59:23 CC What we tried to do was to get the IU frequency shifted off a little bit so that we'd have less interference. I think it'll come up - What we want you to do is turn on your descent oxygen and turn off your ascent oxygen.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: How do you read, Jack? 060:00:46 CC I'm hearing you 5 square, Fred. How me? 060:01:13 CC Aquarius, Houston. How do you read? 060:01:58 LMP Okay.
answer_text: We're up to about 2.6 AGC now. 060:02:03 CC Aquarius, Houston. Radio check. 060:02:10 LMP Okay. Every time you transmit, Jack, the AGC starts to drop off and the static level turns up. 060:02:18 CC Okay, Fred.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Do you think it could be my pitch attitude that's breaking up your incoming? I guess you've been hearing us. 060:04:42 CC We have been hearing you, and the problem is on the ground. I hope we have it corrected now. 060:04:51 CDR Okay.
answer_text: That sounds good. 060:04:53 CC We 're considering powering down the PGNS but we want to know what capability you have to do a coarse and fine aline. We read your conversation about being unable to see out the window very good. How about out the ACT? 060:05:26 LMP He's looking now. 060:05:29 CC Okay.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: How me, now? 060:22:54 CDR Okay, we're reading you loud and clear, Jack. I hope it stays this time. 060:22:58 CC Okay. We'd like to brief you on what our Plan is.
answer_text: We're, at this time, water critical in the LM. So we'd like to use as little as possible. To do this, we're going to plan to make a free- return maneuver of l6 feet per second at 6l hours, which is 37 minutes from now.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Could you give us a little bit more time? 060:24:30 CC Okay, Jim. We'd like to get a suggested time from you. We can figure out a free-return maneuver for any time you want to give us, so if you'll give us the time you'd like to shoot for, we'll figure out a pad. 060:24:47 CDR Okay, that sounds good.
answer_text: I think if we have a little bit more time; we want to do it right. Stand by 1. 060:25:04 CDR Let's shoot for an hour if we can, Jack. How's that. 060:25:15 CC Okay, Jim.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: How about 61 hours and 30 minutes? That's an hour and 5 from now. 060:25:24 CDR Okay. We'll do it and we want to be sure we talk back and forth now to make sure we get this burn off right. 060:25:31 CC Affirm. 060:25:35 LMP Okay, in the interim.
answer_text: Jack, I looked around again and I saw that we have a radar and a landing- radar heater breaker in. Can I pull those out? 060:25:46 CC Affirmative. Pull them both out. 060:25:52 CC And now we want to ask you a question about alinements, and so forth.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: And item 2, I've already got the RCS heaters on. And I don't know if I gave you the time or you got the time on the PRIMARY EVAP FLOW number 1, OPEN. 060:33:04 CC We got the time. 060:33:10 LMP Okay. Let's go to the CB pages now. 060:33:29 CC Fred-o, did you close the engine control breaker in panel 11? 060:33:38 LMP What control is that, Jack? 060:33:40 CC Did you close the S and C engine control breaker on panel 11?
answer_text: As we got step 1 there on page 3. 060:33:49 LMP Okay. Okay, yes, the EPS DESCENT ECA CONTROL breaker is CLOSED on 11. 060:34:00 CC Roger, and how about the - on panel 11, S and C ENGINE CONTROL, CLOSED? AFT OMNI, Fred. 060:34:16 LMP Okay.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Can I pull that? We don't need that, do we? 060:50:32 CC Negative on the ORDEAL. Leave it open. 060:50:48 LMP And how about the ASCENT ECA breaker on panel 11?
answer_text: Jim has it in over there. 060:51:02 CC And panel 11 ASCENT ECA can be open. 060:51:07 CDR It's open. 060:51:27 CC Okay, Aquarius. We're GO on the circuit breaker configuration as you have it now. 060:51:36 SC Roger. 060:52:04 CC And, Aquarius, tests in the simulator just showed that if you want to let the PGNS DAP hold your attitude for you, it will. 060:52:16 CDR Okay, very well. 060:52:30 CDR And, Jack, because it will take quite a while to get back to the attitude, I think we ought to think about going there very shortly. 060:52:37 CC Roger. I have a pad for you.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: How do you like this SIM? 061:05:42 CDR It's a beauty. 061:06:09 CC Okay, Aquarius, we recommend you do the DAP set and gimbal/throttle test as per the checklist. Go PGNS AUTO and proceed. 061:06:21 CDR Well, we're going to fire our thrusters as soon as we go to AUTO because we've got those thrusters in - the thruster circuit breakers. Do you want us to do that and stop? 061:06:50 CC Okay, Aquarius, we're recommending you go to AUTO.
answer_text: Let the thrusters fire and settle down and proceed with the test. 061:07:06 CDR We're in PGNS AUTO. 061:07:09 CC Roger, your DAP is set, you're in wide deadband. That ought to do the trick. 061:07:15 CDR Roger. 061:07:19 CC Okay, we're looking at it, Aquarius. We're ready to proceed with the test. 02 13 07 26 IMP Okay, we're proceeding. 02 13 07 52 IMP Okay, and Houston, you - you're looking at the weights now.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: How does the GDAs look now? 061:11:45 CC The GDAs are GO as they are. Press on. 061:12:09 CDR Okay, Houston, we're going to do the DPS pressurization and checkout. 061:12:16 CC Standby 1. 061:12:34 CC Okay, your gimbals are within 0.3 and we're ready for the DPS pressurization and checkout. 061:13:33 LMP Okay, Houston, do you want to follow up on page 15 with RCS checkout? In essence, we've kind of already done that. 061:13:47 CC You're right, Aquarius.
answer_text: Let's delete the RCS checkout. And a DPS looks GO. 061:15:43 CDR Houston, we're going to do a PGNS AUTO maneuver to the attitude. 061:15:49 CC Stand by on that. Aquarius, we recommend driving it around there manually with a TTCA. 061:15:58 CDR Okay, we'll have to use the TTCA.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Do that with the LGC powered up using the TTCA. After that, we propose to power down the LGC to save some power. However, this means that we lose the use of the TTCA, and we'll have to control the spacecraft with the hand controller in the DIRECT mode.
answer_text: Request your - your position on these two items. 062:27:34 CC Aquarius, Houston. How do you read? 062:27:45 CDR Okay, Jack. Understand.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: When you say power down the DSKY or the LGC, do you mean going into 06 or multiple circuit breaker? 062:30:48 CC Stand by on powering down the DSKY, Jim. We'll give you the procedure for that. The procedure that we- - 062:30:57 CDR Okay. 062:30:58 CC - - the procedure that we have is listed in several places.
answer_text: It's in the Contingency checklist under "Power down" on page 1, second paragraph. 062:31:21 CC And we'll give you that word when we want you to do that. That's LGC only, not to power down the IMU. But we'd like to have you hold off on that until we send you the word.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Do you want those out? 063:19:23 CC Standby 1. 063:19:37 CC Odyssey, Houston. The two circuit breakers you referred to, leave them in. 063:19:45 CMP Okay. Copy.
answer_text: Leave them in. 063:19:59 CDR Okay, Houston. I can control yaw in minimum impulse, but stand by on pitch. 063:20:17 CC And, Fred-o, the DELTA-Vr resultant computes with the components. 063:20:29 CDR Fred's off the C0MM now, Jack. 063:20:32 CC Roger. Your PAD is good. 063:20:35 LMP And, Jack, we didn't get that whole sentence there. 063:20:39 CC Okay.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: I'll get near the bellyband in roll and yaw; then I'll go to PGNS ATT HOLD. 063:28:47 CC That's affirmative, Jim. And then we're going to have you go through a powerdown procedure. 063:28:56 CDR Okay. 063:29:02 CC And you'll need VERB 77 with ATT HOLD when you get there. 063:29:08 CDR Will do. 063:31:48 CDR Okay, Jack. Have I gotten your 360 on yaw and roll?
answer_text: I'm going to go to ATT HOLD. 063:31:56 CC Roger. And then we want to get the ball part down. 063:32:02 CDR Okay. Stand by. 063:32:52 CDR Okay.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: What kind of a ATT HOLD MODE do you want us to do? Do you want us to do WIDE DEADBAND? I didn't ... on the DAP. 063:49:40 CC Jim, the deadband is good the way it is.
answer_text: It's 5 degrees, if you want to stay in it. And stay in the PGNS ATT HOLD mode. 063:49:49 CDR Okay. 063:50:33 CC Two things, Jim. We want you to know that there's some pretty big attitude errors in, so if you go to AUTO, the computer is going to try to crank you around, and the other thing is don't drink water out of the LM. 063:50:54 CDR Okay.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: When it's time for me to make my 90-degree yaw, what I planned on doing was going to NOUN 76 hold and just pulse and yaw several times until the yaw start and hope that pitch and roll stay within the limit. 063:58:37 CC Roger. It sounds like a good plan and you can use your TTCA in MIN IMPULSE to take care of pitch and roll. 063:58:47 CDR Okay. 064:00:21 CC Aquarius, Houston. We see ASCENT 02 tank number 2 building up again, so we'd like to use something out of it, so turn on ascent O2 tank number 2 and turn off descent 02. 064:00:39 CDR Roger.
answer_text: Opening up ascent O2 tank number 2, and turning offf descent. 064:03:01 CC And, Aquarius, Houston. We're starting to think about C02 buildup up in the command module there so we've got a recommendation, and what we're recommending is that you take the commander's hoses in the LM and put a cap over the red return hose and then figure out a way to fasten those hoses so they blow up into the CSM by extending them up through the tunnel as far as possible. And we'll get some flow out the blue side, circulate up and around the command module and to keep the C02 level down. 064:03:43 CDR Roger.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Over. 065:05:50 CDR Disregard it. Okay. Do you want me to start my yaw maneuver now?
answer_text: And I'll be yawing to my right. One-way maneuver. 065:05:59 CC Roger. Right yaw is acceptable, but wait 1 before you start the maneuver. 065:06:09 CDR Roger. 065:06:33 CC Aquarius, Houston. 065:06:38 CDR Go ahead. 065:06:39 CC Okay.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: We have a radio check at a new attitude. 065:34:14 CC Okay, Jim. We copy the angles. How are you receiving the voice now?
answer_text: Over. 065:34:23 CDR Your voice is excellent. 065:34:28 CC Okay. Real good. You are clear.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: How do you read? Over. 065:38:41 CC Okay, Jim, we read you now and you'd better stay in this configuration. 065:39:03 LMP Well, ... try ... 065:39:43 CC Aquarius, Houston. Over. 065:39:50 CDR Go ahead, Houston. 065:39:52 CC Okay, Jim, since we're in LOW BIT RATE now, we cannot monitor the DSKY for program alarms, et cetera, and we recommend that, in order for you to do so on board, you push in the following circuit breakers: On panel 11 and panel l6 the ANUNCIAT0R/D0CK/C0MP0NENT circuit breakers.
answer_text: That will allow you to monitor your DSKY warning lights. Over. 065:40:34 CDR Okay ... 02 17 40 37 IMP ..., OFF. 065:40:42 CDR Roger, Houston. Would you say one more time ... please? 065:40:47 CC Okay, Jim.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: How is the COMM now? Over. 066:11:27 CDR A lot of background noise. Let me turn off the SQUELCH. 066:11:32 CC Okay.
answer_text: You're quite a bit better. 066:11:41 CDR Whenever I enable SQUELCH, I lose you. Over. 066:11:45 CC Roger. Stand by.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: How is it with us? 066:39:26 CC Good. Okay. 066:40:07 CDR Houston, do you want to reconfigure the DOWN VOICE BACKUP again? 066:40:12 CC Aquarius, Houston. I don't think so at this time.
answer_text: Our voice is good now. How's yours? 066:40:22 CDR Ours is very good. 066:40:26 CC Okay, why don't we stay where we are for a few minutes. 067:02:42 CDR Okay. Houston, Aquarius.
