answer_text: On panel - on the second line there under LIGHTING, why are we keeping the FLOODS and TRACK closed? Or are they going to be open? 082:13:33 CC Negative. We have the LIGHTING breakers all closed.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: All of them open. 082:17:15 CDR Closed. 082:17:24 CMP Yes. 082:17:56 CDR Stand by for a MASTER ALARM. 082:17:57 CMP Okay. 082:18:12 CDR Here it comes. 082:18:54 CMP LTG. You just did it. 082:19:18 CDR I'll give you this when I'm finished. After we go through this, then you can go through it again and doublecheck it. 082:19:23 CMP Right. 082:20:07 CMP Now, the flood lights are on, right?
answer_text: No, I kind of don't think we need them though, do you? 082:20:15 CDR Don't pull those. Give me the - first of all We'll get back there. Those four are close, open, open, ENGINE ARM, open, ... 082:22:36 CDR Say, Houston; Aquarius. 082:22:38 CC Go ahead, Aquarius. 082:22:40 CMP It will take him a minute to ... 082:22:43 CDR You're familiar with our particular spacecraft that on panel 16 HEATERS RCS SYSTEMS A and B, QUAD 1 HEATER circuit breaker has been pushed in, and sealed in, and if it's ever pushed out, it's doubtful if we'll ever be able to reset it. 082:23:06 CC Okay, Jim, on the four QUAD HEATER breakers, we want you to leave them closed.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: How me? 083:28:03 CC We're still here, Fred. How's it going? 083:28:11 LMP Okay. My C02 reading is now just below 13. 083:28:21 CC Say again what it is. 083:28:25 LMP It's just - just below 13. 083:28:29 CC Okay.
answer_text: Just below 13. And just for your information, we've got people working on several subjects. We're working on the midcourse coming up to determine our control system and how to do it with the control system we select, what we should do about the alinement.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: How do you read now, Jack? 083:30:45 CC That's a lot better, Fred. 083:30:48 LMP Okay, I just said the Moon is still so bright, that I think probably the higher range of f-stops will be better; f/8, maybe even f/11. 083:31:02 CC Okay. 083:31:11 LMP I can just barely, on the left corner of the Moon now, make out the foothills of Era Mauro formation. We never did get to see it when we were in close, there. 083:31:33 CC Okay. I'm reading on my monitor here, Fred, that you're 16214 miles away from the Moon moving at about 4500 feet per second. 083:31:56 LMP Okay. 083:32:21 LMP From the sounds of all the work that is going on and is still going on, this flight is probably a lot bigger test for the system on the ground than up here. 083:32:41 CC Yes, you've been - you've been working it out a little bit. 083:32:55 LMP Yes.
answer_text: I've really got a tough job right now switching OMNIs. 083:33:08 CC Well, everybody down here is 100-percent optimistic. Looks like we're on the up side of the whole thing now. 083:33:21 LMP Yes, I guess we had better be in good shape, particularly ourselves, rested for that entry day. I think that is going to be a pretty busy one. 083:33:33 CC Right, and we're working on procedures for that.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Could you give us an LPD number periodically? 084:15:02 LMP LPD number? Yes, okay. 084:15:09 CC In fact, if you could give it two or three REVs in a row, why then we could predict where it's going and maybe help us set it up again if we have to. 084:15:22 LMP Okay. 084:15:36 LMP Okay. The center of the Earth has just gone by at an LPD number of 4. 084:15:42 CC Roger.
answer_text: LPD 4, center of the Earth. 084:20:59 LMP And the center of the Moon is about LPD 21. 084:21:04 CC Okay. LPD 21. Is that the center of the Moon, you say? 084:21:11 LMP That's affirm. 084:22:52 CC And, Fred, we're doing a little better on our water than we had anticipated.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Can you identify the quadrant? 086:34:18 CDR Well, I'm looking through the right rear reticle now of the AOT, and when I was back in the command module, I could see it out of the CM 1 window. The particles are rather small, but they are coming out with some force. That's probably what is disturbing our PTC attitude. 086:34:50 CC Yes, that sounds quite probable, Jim.
answer_text: That's about the same report we got from Fred, but we haven't been able to identify what they might be and probably won't be able to until we crank up the CSM. If there's any change in that status, why, we just want to keep advised of it. 086:35:11 CDR Roger. Understand. 086:36:09 CC And, Aquarius, we are setting a pretty good vector on you now.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Do you follow that? 087:06:05 CDR That's affirm. Especially these burns will be perpendicular to our flight path and to the Sun giving a steeper entry angle. 087:06:28 CC Okay, Jim. I heard you say perpendicular to your flight path, which is affirmative, and I didn't get the rest of your statement. 087:06:46 CDR I understand the technique.
answer_text: Jack. We're burning to give us time to steepen our entry angle, and it will be perpendicular to our flight path for corridor control. 087:07:01 CC Okay. That's affirmative.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: When you get ENTER, this will bring ball up to 000, and I want to confirm that you - that you said ENGINE GIMBAL OFF. 0-F-F. Over. 087:15:52 CDR Roger. Confirm that ENGINE GIMBAL will be off. 087:16:11 CDR And, Jack, how long do you estimate the length of the burns will be? 087:16:17 CC Okay.
answer_text: The length of the burns are going to be probably less than a minute. And we want you to have cut-off based on time. So we will give you a burn time.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: What I'm talking about is the control techniques. The way it looks now I'll try to stop the spacecraft in yaw with the Earth out my window. aaen we'll be in GUIDANCE or we'll be AGS CONTROL; we'll be in - yaw will be in MODE CONTROL. Then we'll be using the TTCAs to control the pitch and then control the roll.
answer_text: I don't see another way we can control the combination that we have here without using the TTCAs. Then we will also use the TTCA during engine burn. Do you people concur with that technique? 087:43:05 CC Jim, that sounds like the one that is best to use to me.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Now, maybe you could give Jack the headset and - and - get the equipment together, and we'll talk you through the procedure. I think it'll be a little easier to do that way than if you tried to copy it all down - and then go do it. 090:09:11 CDR Okay. Do you have any equipment listed?
answer_text: I'll just get it and give it to him and I can just sit here where I am. 090:09:17 CC Okay. I think the equipment you'll need will be two command module lithium hydroxide canisters, a roll of the gray tape, the two LCGs, because we're going to use the bags from the LCGs, and one - one LM cue card - one of those cardboard cue cards which you will cut off about an inch and a half out from the ring. Now, I think that's all we'll need.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Now pick up one of the lithium hydroxide canisters, and let me describe which end is which. It's approximately square on one - one of the vented flat ends, has the strap, and that end we call the top, the end opposite we call the bottom. Is that clear?
answer_text: Over. 090:27:21 CMP Right. 090:27:34 CMP Okay. I've got it, Joe. 090:27:37 CC Okay. Now then, we're - we want you to take the tape and cut out two pieces about 3 feet long, or a good arm's length, and what you're - what we want you to do with them is to make two belts around the sides of the canister, one belt near the top and one belt near the bottom, with the sticky side out; wrap it around, sticky side out, as tight as possible.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: The next step now is to anchor that tape, and the way we want you to do that is to cut about a 2-foot length off the roll and then tear it lengthwise so that you have two strips about 2 feet long and about a half an inch wide. And you'll wrap those around the canister at right angles, more or less, to the tape that you've got so that it goes across the top and across the bottom; and when it goes across the top and the bottom, put it so that it's outboard of the center hole and try to get it over one of the ridges between the screens, so that it won't block the flow. Is that clear?
answer_text: Over. 090:34:15 CMP Yes, Joe. Very good. 090:34:17 CC Okay. Press on. 090:34:22 CMP Okay.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: To prevent this from sucking in against the bottom screen, we'd like you to trim it off with the scissors, and when you've done that, we'd like you to cut two more strips of tape about 12 inches long or so, cut the - tear them lengthwise to get four pieces 12 inches long and 1/2-inch wide, and then use those four strips to secure the bag by passing the strips from the sides of the canister outside the bag around the bottom of the canister and back up the other side, and when you do this, just as you did on the top, make them go outward of the hole and in between the screens. Over. 090:53:42 CMP Okay. You want me to trim the excess material. that's sticking off here; trim it at the edge of that canister?
answer_text: Or do you want any excess left over? 090:53:52 CC No, you don't need to have any excess. Just trim it approximately level. 090:53:59 CMP Okay. Let's do that first. 090:54:01 CC Okay. 090:54:58 CMP Okay.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Where you stuff the towel in the bypass hole on the bottom, we recommend that you cut a few short pieces of tape and just tape that over so it doesn't fall out. Over. 091:11:17 CMP Okay. Will do.
answer_text: Jim, I've got one more little thing to do, and that's ... seal that top. 091:12:28 CMP Okay, Joe. That's done. 091:12:30 CC Okay, Jack. Now the remaining steps are simply suit-loop configuration steps to get this thing into full operation, and our ECS people want to hold off on that until the canister you're working on gets to 7.6 millimeters of mercury, which will probably be another 45 minutes or an hour - it - We're reading 4.7 now.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: What we have done is marked up the lift-off configuration checklist, and we'll run through it whenever you get around to it. 091:14:11 CMP And, I assume that ... 091:14:38 CMP What I'd better do is before I put this thing back in operation, they're going to complete that other canister. I don't know. It should be in operation now. ... 091:15:05 CMP Okay, Houston; Aquarius. 091:15:07 CC Aquarius, Houston.
answer_text: Go. 091:15:12 CMP Okay, Joe. Should this canister be in operation now because it's already mounted on the hose? suit loop to get full flow through there, and it's okay the way it is. What I recommend you do with the commander's hose is get the bag all ready, but not stick the hose in until we call you on it.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: How? ... the terminator. 091:33:55 CMP Okay. Now we got to get two strips ... tight. 091:36:52 CMP Tom said the CPCB is getting ... 091:37:01 CDR ... he's never been through a command module activation. 091:37:22 CMP That looks good. Now we got trim up that extra. 091:39:30 CMP ...
answer_text: Well, I don't really - Part of that is - See, Jim, 1 have the same problem that you have. I can't control pitch very well with my RHC - I have to use the THC and that was the control problem. No, I don't think that there's any control problem.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Understand you are ready for the switch configuration checklist. And I have in front of me the lift-off configuration, page L 1-1. Are you with me?
answer_text: Over. 091:53:39 CMP I'm right with you. 091:53:41 CC Okay. I'll read these in bunches of three or four at a time, some of them are the same, some of them are changed, and you can read them back every few steps. EMS FUNCTION to OFF; EMS MODE to STANDBY, no change; GTA, off, down, no change; and GTA cover, secure, no change.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: SPS GAGING, four, to open. 092:17:26 CMP SPS GAGING, four, open. 092:17:31 CC Okay. And SEQ ARM, two, open. 092:17:53 CMP Okay. Are you with me?
answer_text: SEQ ARM, two of them open. 092:17:58 CC Roger. The next is EDS, three, to open. 092:18:05 CMP EDS, three, open. 092:18:08 CC Roger. The next are ELS BAT A, BAT B, two, open. 092:18:27 CMP ELRS RAT A and BAT B, two of them, open. 092:18:30 CC Roger.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: And, on panel 275, we want all the circuit breakers open; no exceptions. Over, 092:34:26 CMP Panel 275, all open; no exceptions. 092:34:30 CC Okay, and that's all for page 1-10. You want to read any of that back?
answer_text: I think you've got it all. 092:34:39 CMP No, I think I've got it all. 092:34:41 CC Okay. Let's go to page 1-11. On panel 276, no change; on panel 278, we want all circuit breakers open; no exceptions.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Then I'll write down that switch configuration, or I'll copy the procedure now, if you want. 092:40:48 CC Yes, okay. Understand they are all up. Did you say you wanted to copy the other procedure now?
answer_text: Over. 092:40:57 CMP I can if you want. It's your choice. 092:41:00 CC I'd rather you went ahead with the switch con- figuration. Jack. 092:41:06 CMP Okay, let's do that and then I'll be back with you. 092:41:10 CC Okay.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: What we are discussing is having you activate the MAIN BUS TIE motor switches a little later on simply to verify that they will be okay, because the batteries are probably getting a little bit cool. But we'll be back to you with a procedure and discussion about that after you get the switch configuration set up. Over. 092:44:47 CMP Okay, I'm going to go get the switch configura- tion done now before Jim goes to bed so I don't disturb him. 092:44:55 CC Okay.
answer_text: Real fine. 092:45:00 CMP Jim thinks Deke sounds like Frank Borman on Apollo 8. 092:45:04 CC (Laughter) Okay. Sorry about that. 092:45:11 CMP I'm going to give the C0MM to Fred-o, now. 092:45:59 CDR Houston, Aquarius. 092:46:02 CC Aquarius, Houston. Go ahead. 092:46:07 CDR Okay, before I hit the sack, Joe, I just want to make sure - How are you still planning an MCC at 107 and what's the latest find? 092:46:16 CC Okay, Jim.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: How do you read now, Joe? 092:59:31 CC Oh, that's much better. Go ahead. 092:59:36 LMP Okay. I was just going to any we haven't had an overboard waste water dump since clear back around the other side of the Moon.
answer_text: About this time, we're running out of the bags we've got on board here. 093:00:03 CC Okay. I'm - I'm stupid this morning, Fred. I'm not quite sure what you are getting at. 093:00:14 LMP Okay, Joe.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: What do you read? 093:23:38 LMP I'm reading about 12.5. I guess we've got a gage problem ... I did just get a MASTER ALARM and no caution light; we kind of figured that's what it was, with CO2 approaching its limit.
answer_text: Maybe it didn't quite come out here. 093:23:59 CC Okay. Let me get a go, and I think it's time for us to go ahead and put these other canisters on. Stand by 1. 093:24:08 LMP Okay.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: How do you read? 093:26:38 CC - - Why don't you try it now? You're loud and clear now, Fred. 093:26:42 LMP Okay. I was just - I'm getting MASTER ALARMS every few seconds and I am catching a glimmer now of the ECS light.
answer_text: For the time being, I have ... - ... open. Okay, now we got the ECS light on steady. 093:27:07 CC Okay. Copy that.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Did you copy my rationale for the main bus powerup? 094:01:45 CMP Yes, I did. You want to remove - You want to power up both buses, with the BUS TIE motor switches; first of all, to sec that there are no loads on the buses, and second, and then depower the buses by pulling the circuit breakers to insure that the motor switches don't - that the BUS TIES stay on so that they're there when we need them. 094:02:09 CC That's correct. Jack.
answer_text: Are you ready to copy the procedure? 094:02:15 CMP Okay. Go ahead. 094:02:16 CC Okay. As the first step, I have one change to the basic configuration that we gave you, and it's two more circuit breakers that we want open.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: How did our ... configurations appear to be working down there? 094:32:54 CC I'm sorry, Fred, but we got noisy again there- 094:33:02 LMP Okay. Let me know when you want me to try it. 094:33:05 CC sounds better already. Go ahead. 094:33:11 LMP Okay.
answer_text: I'd just like to how's - how's our lith-o cartridge setup ... appear to be working down there. 094:33:21 CC We are reading 0.2 on our C02 sets here, and we're all delighted. It seems to be working fine. 094:33:31 LMP Boy, that is great. 094:33:40 CC And Fred, Houston. In a Little while here, I'm going to have a procedure that I want to read up to you and have you copy down for future use.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Are you ready for the procedure, now. Jack? 095:12:55 CMP Yes. Joe, how long is it?
answer_text: Is it a big long one, or a short one, or a medium sized ... about how many pages? 095:13:01 CC It's about - I'd say 15 to 20 steps. Jack. Some of it is LM stuff, and the rest of it is in CSM. 095:13:15 CMP Okay.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: How are you reading on the AFT OMNI. 095:19:11 CC You're okay now. Co ahead. 095:19:15 CMP Okay. After putting the BATTERY B POWER ENTRY/ POSTLANDING on, then I want to push the - on panel 275 MAIN B to BAT BUS B in, huh? 095:19:38 CC That's right.
answer_text: Then you go to verify MAIN BUS voltage, LM POWER to CSM, and then, on panel 275, circuit breaker MAIN B BAT BUS B to open. Over. 095:19:53 CMP Okay. After verifying the MAIN BUS voltage con- necting the LM POWER to CSM I want to pull MAIN B BAT BUS B, or MAIN B to BAT BUS B, open. 095:20:06 CC That's correct.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: For your information, FIDO tells me that we are in the Earth's sphere of influence and we're starting to accelerate. 096:21:29 CMP I thought it was about time we crossed. Thank you. 096:21:33 CC Roger. 096:21:39 CMP We're on our way back home. 096:21:49 CMP There's something that puzzles me, Joe. Vance mentioned yesterday that the planned entry is a CMC-guided entry, so I'm kind of curious as how are we going to get the alinement. 096:22:09 CC Did you say how we're going to get guidance?
answer_text: Over. 096:22:14 CMP No. Row are we going to get a platform alinement? 096:22:18 CC Okay. We got a number of interesting ideas on that and the latest one I've heard is to power up the LM platform and aline it, and aline the CM platform to it. 096:22:32 CMP Okay.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Row about the descent stage? Does Fred report venting down there? Do you still see that? 098:34:33 CDR Stand by. 098:34:36 CDR What is your report on descent stage venting - Was it venting?
answer_text: Anything else going on? Any more venting? 098:34:51 LMP No. 098:34:52 CDR No. Fred hasn't seen anything else from the descent stage.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Do you have? 098:36:10 CC Aquarius, Houston. 098:37:11 CDR Did they give Jack any more procedures, on command module powerup? 04 02 37 16 IMP 098:37:18 CDR Did they give Jack any more procedures on com- mand module powerup? 098:39:04 CDR Well, they think it might be up here. 098:39:06 LMP Okay. 098:39:08 CDR The main thing we got to think about, and when we have to get to them, is the procedures for LM jettison, the transfer of the LM to CSM mode (cough), LM jettison. 04 02 39 23 LMP 098:39:24 CDR Yes. 098:40:33 CDR ... the LM mode? 098:41:17 LMP All we have to do is turn the BIOMED ... on, and we'll be in there. 098:41:34 CDR Houston, Aquarius. 098:41:39 CC Roger. Go ahead, Aquarius. 098:41:44 CDR We would like permission to turn the BIOMED on to get off the hot mike mode. I don't think that we have to be on it now if you have the big dish on, do you? 098:42:05 LMP Yes.
answer_text: Yaw's coming - or roll's coming up for it, and we were going to burn. 098:42:13 CC Roger, Jim. We concur. Go ahead and turn it on. 098:42:18 CDR Okay.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Then, after that, we would establish PTC again. 098:43:16 CDR Roger. 098:48:01 CDR Houston, Aquarius. 098:48:05 CC Go ahead, Aquarius. 098:48:09 CDR Our REPRESS package pressure is 820. 098:48:14 CC Okay. REPRESS pressure 820. Thank you. 098:54:17 CC Aquarius, Houston. 098:54:23 CDR Go ahead, Houston. 098:54:26 CC Jim, could you switch your BIOMED switch to the position opposite to where it is now?
answer_text: We are getting a subcarrier, but no data. Over. 098:54:45 CDR Now you know, Houston, I don't have BIOMED on. 098:54:53 CC Okay. And we have a small addition to the pro- cedure that was read up to you earlier, which involves power transfer from the LM to the CSM. 098:55:17 CDR Stand by 1. 098:55:19 CC Okay. 098:55:59 CDR Okay, Houston.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Could you turn off battery 2, and leave it off and let us look at it? 099:53:36 CDR Say again. You want us to turn off battery 2, and leave it off until you look at it? 099:53:39 CC That's affirmative. 099:53:42 CDR Okay. Battery 2 coming off the line. 099:54:27 CC Okay, Aquarius.
answer_text: So you want to stay in this configuration for awhile, and let's look at the battery. 099:54:34 CDR Roger. We'll stay in this configuration. 099:54:41 CC Want to close the BAL LOADS circuit breaker back now. 099:55:00 CC 13, Houston- We want to close the BAL LOADS circuit breaker on panel l6 now, again. 099:55:08 CDR We have it closed; the closed - BALANCE LOADS circuit breaker is closed. 099:55:13 CC Roger. 099:55:41 CC Aquarius, Houston. Request RANGE FUNCTIONS switch to RANGE ... 099:55:49 CDR All right.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: What we're trying to do here is we're getting you set up in an attitude so you can damp your rates and come out of FTC. And this is the configuration I'm reading you now, the next - in the next six lines, the procedure for getting you into a configuration to damp the rates and stop PTC. Over. 100:15:43 CDR Okay.
answer_text: So the first thing will be to - "Go to AUTO on the RCS SYSTEM A and B"? 100:15:50 CC It's the "Verify that the heaters have been in AUTO for 15 minutes." Back on the first page of this procedure, you put the heaters in AUTO and you pushed the breakers in, and we'd like for them to warm up the quads for 15 minutes before we start to - stop at - stopping PTC. Over. 100:16:12 CDR Roger, "Verify heaters RCS on for 15 minutes." 100:16:16 CC Okay. Step 2: "BALANCE COUPLE, OFF; DEAD BAND, MINIMUM; ATTITUDE CONTROL: PITCH and ROLL to PULSE; YAW to DIRECT; MODE CONTROL: AGS, ATT HOLD; GUIDANCE CONTROL to AGS; damp rates; pitch and roll with the TTCA, yaw with the ACA with the Earth in the front window." Over. 100:17:45 CDR Okay, let's see if I got it.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: What happens is, of course, we set - when you go out of detent, you reset the AGS error needles and you - and you lose your attitude reference. You establish a new attitude reference, and it might not be the burn attitude since, at this point, we're controlling attitude with the TTCA. Now, picking up with the "VERB 37, ENTER," scratch.
answer_text: Scratch everything down to the "404 plus zero," and we want you to perform those AGS steps with 404 down through 470. Over. 100:31:23 CDR Okay. We'll scratch everything down to "404 plus zero," and we'll perform those four steps. 100:31:29 CC Roger.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: When rates are less than 0.05, ATTITUDE CONTROL: YAW, to PULSE." 100:41:52 CDR Okay, Charlie. Can you hold up here a second? I lost you. 100:41:55 CC Roger. 100:42:00 CDR Start with step 3 again.
answer_text: "When attitude - When at attitude, ACA out of detent." 100:42:09 CC That's Roger. Next step, step 4: "ATTITUDE CONTROL to YAW" - Correction, "ATTITUDE CONTROL: YAW, to MODE CONTROL." Over. 100:42:33 CDR Okay. Step 4 is "ATTITUDE CONTROL: YAW, to MODE CONTROL." 100:42:37 CC Roger.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Why don't you read that group back, and then we'll proceed on. 101:11:39 CMP Okay, sounds good. Because I don't know where I - how far I lost you. Okay, panel 4; TELCOMM, GROUP 1, to ACl.
answer_text: On panel 5, close the following circuit breakers: ECS, PRESSURE GROUP 1, MAIN B; ECS, PRESSURE GROUP 2, MAIN B; ECS, TEMP, MAIN B; ECS, SECONDARY LOOP TRANSDUCER, MAIN B; ECS RAD, CONTROL/HEATERS, MAIN B; BAT RELAY BUS, BAT B; BAT CHARGER, BAT B; INVERTER CONTROL, 2; INVERTER CONTROL, 1; EPS SENSOR SIGNAL, ACl; EPS SENSOR SIGNAL, MAIN B; EPS SENSOR UNIT, ACl; WASTE/ POTABLE HO, MAIN B; INSTRUMENTATION, ESSENTIAL, MAIN B. 101:12:41 CC Okay. That's all correct. Is that reading rate okay for you? 101:12:48 CMP Yes, that's fine. 101:12:50 CC Okay, and leave a little space if you can to the right of these because when we talk about the backup procedure, why then we can just use the same listing, and I'll - I'll tell you open instead of close these circuit breakers, or at least most of them.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: What I just gave you now on the backout is the only thing that's order critical. From here on, you can go to the steps for initiating the procedure, and backtrack. In other words, you should go to each of the panels that I read up and put the circuit breakers back to the base-line configuration - or the switches.
answer_text: Over. '. 101:28:56 CMP Okay, now here's - to accent, here's the sequence-critical sets: POWER AMPL, OFF; TRANSPONDER, OFF; AC INVERTER, 2, OFF; and the last one on panel 250, CB BAT Baker POWER ENTRY/ POSTLANDING, open; and then hit the steps in reverse order that you gave them to me, and back out, like then I would start on MDC 3 UP TELEMETRY, OFF - to OFF; and then AC INVERTER - ACl BUS 1 to OFF; and then AC INVERTER, 2, OFF; AC INVERTER, 2, MAIN B to OFF. Is that the type of order that you want to back out of? 101:29:59 CC That's affirm, but - just for kicks, let's go through these panels again, and I'll give you the - the position, just to make sure there can be no doubt. 101:30:18 CMP Okay.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: No, this is independent of power from the LM. This is a - this is purely a CSM - - 101:35:42 CMP Okay. 101:35:43 CC This is purely a CSM powerup so we can take a look at your telemetry and see how cold the vehicle is and that sort of thing. 101:35:55 CMP Okay. It's going in work. 101:36:03 CMP Okay, now I won't - I won't have any voice with you, so - Is that right?
answer_text: You don't want me to get connected up - you want me to just take these readings and come back and tell you what I have, huh? 101:36:17 CC That's affirm. There'll be no voice. And - - 101:36:22 CMP Okay.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Which circuit breaker was that? 102:59:28 CDR It was - It was the battery charge circuit breaker that allows you to read volts, but we haven't - don t know the exact name for it yet. 102:59:39 CC Okay. Understand. 102:59:48 CDR The name is BATTERY CHARGER BAT B CHARGE Jack tells me. 102:59:52 CC Okay. BATTERY CHARGER BAT B CHARGE. 103:00:22 CC Aquarius, Houston. 103:00:25 CDR Go ahead. 103:00:28 CC Have you opened your - just curiosity - Have you opened your food locker just aft of the LM data file?
answer_text: Over. 103:00:51 CDR Yes. It's been opened. 103:00:55 CC Okay. Just cheeking.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: How does that ...? 104:31:23 CC Okay. FIDO's hustling here. We'll try to get it right up to you.
answer_text: Stand by. 04 08 32 10 CDR 104:32:13 CC Aquarius, Houston. Over. 104:32:18 CDR We have ... 104:32:37 CC Aquarius, Houston. Over. 104:32:41 CDR Vance, we have the quad heaters on, now. 104:32:44 CC Roger.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: I've held up long enough. 105:42:32 LMP That's coming from above. Another one just - is just coming down right over here- Well, there's the old terminator at Fra Mauro. We'd been landing about 2 hours ago, huh?
answer_text: Right on the - - 105:42:56 CDR Houston, Aquarius. 105:42:57 LMP - - to the right of the terminator. 105:42:59 CC Go ahead, Aquarius. 105:43:03 CDR Just for information, although l thought I'd never have to use it, that technique looked like it was a pretty good one. 105:43:13 CC Roger, Jim. And we'd like you to give us your idea of how the PTC looks- We're not sure we're seeing what we ought to here. 105:43:26 CDR Okay. I still have my ball powered up and I'm coming around past 270 right now.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Okay. 105:44:22 LMP First row. Ullage. AGS. 105:44:31 CMP Your AGS on? 105:44:33 LMP My what?
answer_text: My what? Oh, yes. Go ahead. 105:44:38 CDR Okay.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: What a way to get a data point. 108:26:35 CDR And, Jack, just think. You thought you we'-e going to sleep through all your watches. 108:26:41 CC Say again, Jim. 108:26:48 CDR I said, you thought you were going to sleep through all you watches. 108:26:58 CC Well, you keep waking me up. 108:27:04 CDR Sorry about that. 108:54:31 CC Aquarius, Houston. You notice anything? 108:54:37 CDR Yes, Jack.
answer_text: I was just about ready to call you. Underneath quad 4, I noticed a lot of sparklies going out. 108:54:50 CC Can you hear or feel anything? 108:54:54 CDR No, I sure can't, but I think it changed our - it changed out PTC. Let me check and see what the drift is. 108:55:09 CC Okay.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Could you give us high bit rate for a while, please? 109:16:13 CC Aquarius, Houston. High bit rate, please. 109:16:19 LMP How you getting it now. Jack? 109:16:23 CC We got it. 109:20:54 CC Okay, Aquarius.
answer_text: You can go low bit rate, POWER AMP, OFF and DOWN VOICE BACKUP now. Voltages and currents look normal on battery 2; so ignore the battery light. 109:21:12 CMP Okay, Jack. POWER AMP, OFF, back to low bit rate, and I'll go back to sleep. 109:21:21 CC The battery light staying on? 109:21:30 CMP Yes.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: What do you think? 110:23:36 CDR Yes, go ahead. It's okay. 110:23:40 CC Okay. One of the first things we want to do is charge the battery in CSM, so we can get some LM power over there to do that, and we have procedures ginned up to do it.
answer_text: In regards to reentry, we're planning our last midcourse at 5 hours before entry interface, and, if we have to make one, that is. And then we'd like to jettison the service module at 4 hours and a half, roughly, before entry interface, and take the next 3 to 3-1/2 hours for taking pictures, cranking up the command module G&N, taking care of stowage, and other odds and ends. And we'd hang on to the LM until 1 hour before entry interface, and then we'd jettison that.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: How we aline the command module right for entry, especially if you have the LM in back. Over. 110:32:21 CC Roger. That's one subject that's been getting a lot of attention, and let me see if I can get 110:32:33 CDR Okay. 110:35:36 CC Jim, I can give you the general idea of the proposed procedure for bringing the command module G&N up.
answer_text: It's the presently proposed one. We may come up with a better one, but here's what we're looking at right now. First thing we plan to do is to - using the LM COAS, sight on the Earth with the LM just as we did in the midcourse.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Do you follow all that? 110:37:05 CDR Okay, Jack. Let me see if I have it. What we do is point the LM at the Earth as we did for the midcourse COAS, and we do a body-axis aline on the AGS.
answer_text: Then you give us an AGS ball attitude to fly to. ... the LM, and then we ... point the ... at the Moon. Then you would update the - give us some CDUs to coarse aline. ... fine aline ... on stars or the Moon or the Earth. Stand by.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: What did Jim want to know? 111:03:10 CMP Okay. He would like to know whether the proceure has been tried and whether it has been found to be okay; and there's no danger of shorting out any of our batteries or anything we have on board the LM now. 111:04:20 CC Okay, Jack. This procedure has not been tried out as such; however, the hardware paths through which the current flows are the same ones which we used during translunar trajectory, and there's not a problem with shorting out a descent battery.
answer_text: Over. 111:04:47 CMP Okay. I'll relay that to Jim. 111:05:09 CC Jack, of course, the reason for all of this is that we see we're 20 amp-hours short on one of the entry batteries, and we've got to juice that up to get you home with. 111:05:25 CMP Okay. 111:05:30 CC Okay. What we owe you from here on out is the actual battery A charge procedure, and then a procedure to turn this all around, again. 111:05:48 CMP Okay.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Do you have it there, and how long is it ... 111:06:15 CC Okay, Jack. I have the procedure in front of me. It's about 18 steps, and the reason it's so long is because we're starting from this basic configuration which we gave you earlier.
answer_text: It concerns a charge on battery A, of course, which is our low one. So, when you're ready to copy it, let me know. 111:06:40 CMP Okay. Let's go at it. 111:06:46 CC Okay.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: How do you read, now? 111:12:03 CC Okay. I'm reading you real good now, and I want to verify that the main bus tie that we switched OFF was BAT Alfa Charlie. 111:12:15 CMP That's verified; MAIN BUS TIE, BAT Alfa Charlie OFF. And that should ... 111:12:22 CC Okay.
answer_text: And in panel 3, I've got a switch for you. AC INVERTER 2 to MAIN B. 111:12:39 CMP Okay. AC INVERTER 2 to MAIN B. 111:12:42 CC Okay.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: No, we can't put the in our SRC, but we could put them in that container down there which would help decrease our L over D. Anything else you can think of would be greatly appreciated because we don't even have a throwaway station, so we're down a little bit in L over D. 111:34:33 CC Okay. Let me pass that question along, and get somebody working on it. 111:35:03 CC Souvenirs, I guess. 111:35:09 CMP What souvenirs?
answer_text: (Laughter) All I've got is a Marine Corps foxhole-digging shovel. 111:35:19 CC You've got all you need then, buddy. 111:35:27 CC Okay. Ready to copy the power removal from the command module/LM umbilical. 111:35:35 CMP I'm ready to copy. Go ahead. 111:35:40 CC Okay.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: What I got, Jack, was the procedure assumes that all DESCENT BATTERIES are ON, and BAT 6 is on NORMAL FEED. Now we're going into the LM and on panel 5, we take LM, or CB LM POWER-2, MAIN B open. And that's as far as I got. 111:37:18 CC Okay, the second one is on panel 5 also.
answer_text: Circuit breaker, LM POWER-l, MAIN A, open; circuit breaker EPS SENSOR SIGNAL, MAIN B, open. Okay, read those back for the CSM, and I'll give you some steps in the LM. 111:37:40 CMP Okay. 111:37:58 CMP Okay. CB LM POWER-2, MAIN B, open; CB LM POWER-l MAIN A, open; CB EPS SENSOR SIGNAL, MAIN B open Stand by 1, Jack. 111:38:15 CMP Jack, I don't think we ever closed CB IM P0WER-1 MAIN A.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Do you have anything more for the command module? 111:41:43 CC We're discussing two items, but we don't have them ready right now. 111:41:56 CMP One of them, I hope, is a foolproof alinement procedure. 111:42:37 CMP Okay, Jack. Just for curiosity's sake, does FIDO have any information as to whether that helium - that helium tank dump affected our trajectory at all? 111:43:21 CC Okay, Aquarius. Our tracking data shows that since the helium dump, our ertry angle has not changed from its; value of 6.24, and somebody calculated that if we had a propulsive vent, that helium could roughly, at the maximum, only impart a DELTA-V of a half a foot per second or less, anyway.
answer_text: But we're continuing to track and as soon as we get some more info, we'll pass it along. 111:43:57 CMP Okay. That's swell, Jack. Thank you. 111:44:00 CC Sure. 111:44:01 CMP Your 6.24 sounds good. 111:44:14 CDR I'm still awake, I guess. 111:44:22 CMP They said that it would be a while because they want to get high bit rate.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: We've just looked through the A0T and you can't see anything back there. 112:14:00 CC Okay. And everything's fine in El Lago. 112:14:06 LMP Very good. 112:15:42 CC Aquarius, we're ready to secure the high bit rate. 112:15:48 LMP Okay. 112:16:32 LMP Houston, Aquarius; how do you read? 112:16:38 CC I'm hearing you with a lot of background noise Fred-o. 112:16:42 LMP Okay. How now?
answer_text: I just switched OMNIs again. 112:23:32 CC Aquarius, could you get a - amps and volts readout from Odyssey, please? 112:23:45 LMP Okay, stand by. 04 16 24 08 LMP The CMP is dotting across there. You'd be amazed at how proficient you get at transfering to the tunnel after the first 1000 times. 112:24:31 CC I didn't get your last there, Fred-o. We'd like you to verify that your POWER AMPLIFIER circuit breaker is open. 112:24:44 LMP Okay.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: We think we lost lock in Madrid for a while, and we've got it back now. 114:57:07 CMP Okay. Real fine. ... 114:57:11 CC Okay. 114:57:13 CMP You might also check with FIDO whether we ... perigee ... 114:57:23 CC You're getting a little weak. Did you say you wanted to verify what - what your vacuum perigee is?
answer_text: Over. 114:57:30 CMP Yes. ... 114:58:35 CC Jack, Houston. Over. 114:58:39 CMP Go ahead. 114:58:41 CC Okay. The good FIDO gives us a vacuum perigee at the present time of 23.6 with a flight path angle of minus 6.25 degrees.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Do you read? 116:29:53 CC Aquarius, Houston. Okay; go ahead. 116:29:58 CDR Volts, 39.3; amps, 1.25. 116:30:06 CC Okay. Copied 39.3 and 1.25.
answer_text: Jim, did jack tell you what your trajectory looks like? Over. 116:30:18 CDR Haven't got up to ... on it. How about giving me a rundown? 116:30:21 CC Okay.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: We'd like the descent tank temperatures, too. Over. 117:01:59 CDR 67; oxidizer is 63; descent tank 1 ... is 64; the oxidizer is ... Did you copy?
answer_text: Over. 117:02:22 CDR Hello, Houston. Did you copy the - the DPS display temperatures? 117:02:27 CC Jim, I copied 63 and 64, which I think were the descent 1 temps, and that's all I got. 117:02:37 CDR Okay. I'll go over it again.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: What happened was, our lithium hydroxide device here got caught in the suit relief valve. It is closed now. That's where you want it, right? 118:44:12 CC Okay. 118:44:30 CC Okay. 118:44:45 CDR And, Joe, just a reminder; now that you mention it - that it's less than 24 hours to go, what I'd like to do, and I have aboard all the Procedures that you are working up; so I can run through them with the crew, and make sure that we get all our signals straight. 118:45:05 CC Roger that, Jim.
answer_text: We are trying to get the procedures finished and up to you as quickly as we can. They exist. What's going on now is the guys are running them in the CMS/LMS, integrate, to make darn sure that the attitudes are correct and the time line is nice and relaxed and all that good stuff.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: What we expect to have for you shortly are procedures which we'll try and get up to you in the following form. First, we'll have a time line, sort of a flight plan thing, which will have the times of all the major events and any configurations, switch settings, and so forth which are peculiar to our configuration and which, therefore, you won't find in the checklist. This, for instance, will be true of the way we power up the command module; and second, of course, we'll have any redlines to the checklist so that you can enter the checklist where possible to - to perform functions, and the time line will simply refer you to the checklist when that's appropriate.
answer_text: Okay? 120:23:32 CDR Okay. Sounds good. You're going to give me an overall time line now, I take it; is that right? 120:23:36 CC That's affirm.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Could you give us battery A voltage ... reading, please, and battery charger current, as you have been doing. 120:57:54 CDR Okay, Vance. Standby. 120:57:56 CC Okay. 120:59:11 CDR Houston, Aquarius. 120:59:13 CC Go ahead, Jim. 120:59:16 CDR Okay. Volts are 39.5; amps, 1.25. 120:59:23 CC Roger.
answer_text: Copy 39.5; and 1.25. Thank you. 121:47:31 CC Aquarius, Houston. Over. 121:47:37 CDR Aquarius here.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Why don't you make a note of this one item? Forget about the LM - - 122:49:07 LMP Stand by; stand by l. 122:49:08 CC Okay. 122:49:14 LMP I think Jack hauled off the piece of paper with that - all that on it. Why don't you hold it until Jack gets done doing the battery charge? 122:49:24 CC Okay. 122:49:39 CC And, Fred, request PCM on L0 bit rate, now. 122:49:44 LMP Okay.
answer_text: And there was one piece of flight data that we needed that we didn't bring along this time. 122:50:00 CC What was that? 122:50:04 LMP That's a big book with a lot of just plain old blank pages in it. 122:50:10 CC Yes, when you - when you get off nominal, why you just need scratch paper, don't you? 122:50:17 LMP Yes. 122:51:28 LMP Okay, Vance. I got the stowage list now. 122:51:32 CC Okay, I gave you two lists - - 122:51:33 LMP And Jack's got - and Jack said he's completed - the - secured the battery charge now. 122:51:44 CC Okay, and we're recording the time that that was complete. You have two lists there, one is LM to CM equipment transfer and the second list is the reverse.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Do you want the same readouts from me that I gave you before? 122:56:34 CC That's affirmative, Jack. And just to make sure that there is no mistaking the procedure, it starts out for the backout part: panel 3, POWER AMPL, OFF; TRANSPONDER, OFF; AC INVERTER 2, OFF; then goes to panel 250, et cetera. 122:57:07 CMP That's - that's the way I read it. 122:57:09 CC Okay. 122:57:13 CMP Okay; going back up into the refrigerator. 122:57:17 CC Hey, I thought it was the bedroom. 122:57:22 CMP Well, it's got a new name now, because it is about 30 degrees cooler. 122:57:30 CC Roger. Returning to the deep freeze - - 122:57:31 CMP - - Hey, Vance.
answer_text: One thing that I wanted to ask you - is on the stowage list where you have us putting the black-and-white TV camera on top of A-7 in an A ... decontamination bag, I was wondering if it would be possible or if you - there would be any problem in putting it into B-6 along with the two 70-millimeter Hasselblad cameras? 122:58:02 CC Jack, I don't think there'll be any problem, if you can get it in, but let us get - work that and get back with you. Okay? 122:58:10 CMP All right. I was just thinking.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Just let us know when he does it. 123:11:56 LMP Okay. 123:11:59 CC And, after that, we'll start the battery charge, and we'll have to know when he starts that. 123:12:07 LMP Okay. He's starting to back out now. Just out of curiosity, what - did you all get a readout on what the cabin temp was up there? 123:12:20 CC Yes, we're getting 45 to 46 degrees. 123:12:31 LMP Now you see why we call it the refrigerator. 123:12:35 CC Yes, it's kind of a cold winter day up there, isn't it?
answer_text: Is it snowing in the command module yet? 123:12:50 LMP Is it what, Vance? 123:12:52 CC Is it snowing in there yet? 123:12:59 LMP Oh, snowing. No-no, not quite. The windows are in pretty bad shape, and I guess the service module - we'll be trying to shoot out of the LM window, because every window in the command module is just covered with water droplets.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: It's going to take a lot of scrubbing to get those cleared off. 123:13:21 CC Roger. Understand. Pete says to tell you that you'll have some time on the beach in Samoa to thaw out after this cold experience. 123:13:37 LMP Hey, that sounds great. 123:14:01 LMP Vance, have you all thought about what cameras you wanted to use?
answer_text: Right now, we've got configured a Hasselblad with a 250, and I've got the lunar-surface number 1 Hasselblad, and I've got the lunar surface sequence camera, also, rigged and ready to go. Did you have any other druthers about the ... 123:14:26 CC You are referring to the photography of the ser- vice module, is that right? 123:14:32 LMP That's right. 123:14:33 CC We have some procedures in work, and I've seen them, Fred. I think pretty soon we'll be shooting them up to you to specify which cameras and settings.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: How about - You ready for some other readouts, that you wanted there? 123:22:40 CC Ready to copy. 123:22:44 CMP Okay. BAT B, 37.0; pyro A, 37.0; pyro B, 37.0; SPS helium pressure, 3400; and nitrogen A and B - just for throwing it in for kicks, 2200 and 2400, respectively; and the injector temperature - stand by - The Sun went down. Okay.
answer_text: The injector temperature, 5 Charlie, 3.9; 5 Dog, 3.2; 6 Alfa, 3.6; 6 Baker, 3.9; 6 Charlie, 3.5; 6 Dog, 3.4; the battery manifold pressure, 1.4. 123:24:01 CC Okay. We copy all that, Jack. Thank you. 123:24:04 CMP Okay. 123:24:20 CMP You say, you figure you are going to be charging BAT A until about 126? 123:24:32 CC Roger.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Essentially, what you wanted to use as far as the movie camera in the LM goes, is our lunar sequence camera which is attached to the powerpack. We use the l8-millimeter lens, set it at 12 frames per second ... f:8 at 250th of a second. 124:45:22 CC Roger. f:8 at 250th. 124:45:30 CDR Right; f:8 at 250th. 124:45:35 CC Okay. Would you believe that we have a correc- tion now to the last camera I gave you?
answer_text: Correct that 18-millimeter lens to 75-millimeter lens. 124:45:52 CDR Okay. The 18-millimeter to the 75-millimeter lens. Okay. 124:45:57 CC Right.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Sorry to wake you up for this, but take about a minute, and then we'll read it up to you. 125:30:07 CC Aquarius, Houston. 125:30:12 CMP Okay, Vance. Go ahead. 125:30:14 CC Okay, Jack. Do you have any of that CM water - bagged water, left?
answer_text: Over. 125:30:22 CMP Negative. I went up and tried to repressurize the surge tank and get another shot of water, and was able to repressurize the surge tank okay, but there was no water that came out of the water tank. 125:30:36 CC Ye's. We understand that there isn't any more in the potable tank, but we understood that you had put some water from that tank into bags, and I wondered if any of the bags were left. 125:30:48 CMP Negative. 125:30:50 CC Okay. 125:33:42 CC Okay, Jack.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: How do you read? 126:12:40 CC Okay. And next step, panel 12: S-BAND FUNCTION to VOICE and RANGING FUNCTION to RANGING. 126:13:25 CMP Okay, Vance. The S-BAND FUNCTION is at VOICE and the RANGING switch was at RANGING. 126:13:32 CC Okay.
answer_text: That makes it so we can hear you better, Jack. 126:13:41 CMP Okay. Can we - Since the first part of it, you're just going to read and I'm going to copy and we're going to have a question and answer period later, can we get started? 126:13:52 CC Okay. Procedure's coming back in again.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Could you say it - the EI minus 4 dash - or 04:40, we do something. 126:31:15 CC Okay. And at that time, you'll want to perform step 39 of Page E/l-6. Over. 126:31:31 CMP Okay.
answer_text: Perform step 39 of entry checklist page E/l-6. 126:31:39 CC That's correct. Okay. The next is the command module RCS activation, and that's step 4-1 of page E/l-6. 126:32:13 CMP Okay.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Are they ON now. Ken? I don't remember turning them - I guess that's part of one of the other sequences, huh?
answer_text: That we turned them ON? 126:39:08 CC That's affirm. The reason we're turning the logic off, Jack, is a power savings. So we'll be turning them off, and I'll ge getting them back on when we go to get off of the LM; and then turn them back off, then we'll be turning them on prior to entry.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: That will be at EI minus 19 minutes, and we're off and running through a normal sequence of events. 127:48:32 CMP Okay. That sounds good. Ken, I guess if you've read this thing - Is it a comfortable time line?
answer_text: Any areas where you had problems with? 127:48:42 CC Jack, it is very comfortable. We've run it several times now and, in fact, it's being run right now, again. And we've run it both here at Houston and at the Cape.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: When COMM is lost, SCE POWER OFF, PMP POWER OFF. 127:52:47 CC That's correct. Jack, and that completes the entry checklist. Let's look at the G&C book. 127:53:06 CMP Okay.
answer_text: Ready to copy. 127:53:08 CC Okay. Let's go to page 2-1. 127:53:25 CMP Okay. Go ahead. 127:53:27 CC Okay, Jack.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Do you have that backout procedure in your hand there? 128:05:20 CMP Yes, I do, Vance. 128:05:22 CC Okay. Just to verity. It starts out panel 3, BATTERY CHARGE switch, OFF; AC INVERTER 2, OFF; panel 5, MAIN BUS TIE, BAT A/C, on, up, et cetera. 128:05:40 CMP Roger.
answer_text: Continues CB BAT A, POWER ENTRY/ POSTLANDING, open; INVERTER POWER 2, MAIN B, open; and then you reverse the steps that yen had for entering the procedure. 128:05:54 CC Yes, that's fine. Okay. And we have one other comment regarding the systems checklist, and stand by 1, and that'll - that'll wrap it up for us.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: How do you read? 128:11:14 CMP Roger. Loud and clear. 128:11:16 CC Okay. We want you to vent - tunnel vent until, and add the following, "Until LM/CM DELTA-P is equal to 3.0 psid." 128:11:42 CMP Okay.
answer_text: "Until LM/CM DELTA-P equals 3.0." 128:11:47 CC Okay. And that means that you'll have a pressure of 1.5 to 2 in the tunnel, absolute. That's - - 128:11:57 CMP Okay. 128:11:58 CC That's a note. 128:12:01 F Jack, that's what we want to end up with ultimately is 1-1/2 to 2 there in that tunnel and depending on the gage reading, bit that should be about 3. 128:12:10 CMP Okay, Deke. 128:12:12 CC Okay, then, Jack.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Okay. That's all for that page, Fred. That should add up to six circuit breakers all closed, on that page. 129:08:39 CDR Vance, Jim. 129:08:41 CC Go ahead, Jim. 129:08:43 CDR Have we looked seriously now at just the essential things required to make a safe LM jettison?
answer_text: We're not - I don't think we have the time to really do any engineering data that people might want to look at as this thing goes into the atmosphere. 129:09:06 CC Well, Jim. I - I think that that was what every- body aimed for, and people down here feel that it's the essentials, that it's what you need. 129:09:19 CDR Well, we'll do everything you think is essential, but I just don't want to be throwing switches at the last minute. What we're really thinking about, getting that command module in good shape. 129:09:35 CC Hey, Jim.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: So if you'll pick that up, I'll give it to you. 132:31:25 LMP Okay. Which one? 132:31:29 CC Okay. Stand by 1. 132:31:33 LMP Is it the one Jack wrote them all in?
answer_text: The big long readout? He also wrote something in the G&N book. 132:31:41 CC It's in the big, long one he wrote out at about EI minus 02:30. EMS entry check. 132:31:51 LMP Okay.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Do it as we've outlined it in the procedure, in that order. Over. 132:44:33 LMP Okay. That's the way we planned on it.
answer_text: We'll let Jack do his three and then he'll tell us when we're GO from there. What pages are those changes on? 132:44:48 CC Okay, Fred. The one I've got for you is at the end of power removal from the command module LM umbilical.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Did you want those in, too, or are we just going to use one set of heaters? 133:31:02 CC Stand by. 133:31:32 CC Aquarius, Houston. Go as the checklist recommends for now. When you get into the circuit breaker panel configuration, you're going to get the number 1 set of heaters on anyway. 133:31:44 LMP Okay. 133:34:14 LMP Okay, Houston.
answer_text: We'd like to get a hack to set our mission timer here, Jack. 133:34:21 CC Okay, Fred-o. Set it at 133:35 straight up. You've got about 30 seconds to set it. 133:34:49 LMP Okay.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: When you look out a detent 2 in the proper burn attitude, what you ought to see is the Sun at 12 o'clock, about halfway between the top of the A0T and the center of the pipper. And you ought to see the Earth - - 134:01:03 LMP Okay. 134:01:04 CC - - at 6 o'clock. 134:01:07 LMP Okay. 134:01:41 CDR And, it's getting a little warmer in here now. Thank you. 134:01:58 CC Duck blinds are always warmer, Jim, when the birds are flying. 134:02:06 CDR Right. 134:02:47 CDR Jack, I've gotten so used to flying attitude with the TTCA, I won't be able to do it normally. 1 134:02:56 CC Say again, Jim. 134:02:59 CDR I said I've gotten so used to flying attitude with the translational control, I won't be able to do with the ACA. 134:06:06 CC Aquarius, we see your glycol temperature getting up there.
answer_text: If you want to make it a little warmer, or you can try putting your SUIT TEMP valve to HIGH, if you haven't already got it there. 134:06:25 LMP Okay. 134:10:45 CC Aquarius, something we're thinking about right now is, if we can do it without using a lot of RCS, it would be to our advantage timewise to try to get an alinement. 134:11:00 CDR Okay. You mean a P52? 134:11:05 CC We're - - 134:11:06 CDR I'lll ... around. 134:11:07 CC A combination of 51 and 52. 134:11:15 CDR I'll see what we can do. Jack. 134:11:18 CC Okay.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: What you're reading now the angles? We had the Moon centered, and it's pretty close to what we have on the 8 ball, I guess. Close enough for any entry that we'd like to do. 135:10:20 CC Roger.
answer_text: And I'm told that Denubla - Denebola and Regulus are nearby if you wanted to make a star check. 135:10:35 CDR Okay. I'm going to start pitching around again, and I'll see if I can pick them up. I have Orion out here to my left a little bit, but it's pretty close to the - oh, here.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Do you plan something like that or just three coarse aline angles. 135:49:53 CC Jack, we're going to give you three coarse aline angles, and then you can go right to your checklist as we're giving it, and start in with the VERB 40 NOUN 20. 135:50:07 CMP Okay. Real fine. 135:52:45 LMP And, Jack, how do you lead? 135:52:48 CC Fine - square. 135:52:54 LMP I was around shooting pictures of all the debris inside here, before we left, and I inadvertently changed the settings on the DC command module Reseau camera that we need for the service module pictures. I wonder if FA0 can dig them out again - what we need, f-stop and speed. 135:53:18 CC Okay, Fred.
answer_text: Stand by. 135:54:55 CC Fred, in regards to the camera settings, for black-and-white 3400 film, the settings were f:5.6 at l/250th. Over. 135:55:09 LMP Okay. I'd guessed right after all, but thank you. 136:04:59 CC Aquarius, Houston.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Do you want to copy that for Jack? Over. 136:16:10 LMP Stand by. I'll have to try to borrow his book from him. 136:16:14 CC Roger. 136:16:17 CDR Can we hold off on that a little bit, Joe? 136:16:19 CC 0h, absolutely, Jim.
answer_text: We're well ahead. I just wanted to let you know that we had it. 136:16:25 CDR okay. I hope that when you send up all those uplinks to Jack that you could get them up to him quickly. 136:16:33 CC We're shooting for less than 5 minutes. 136:16:38 CDR Sounds good. 136:16:43 LMP And are you still using the computer? 136:16:46 CC That's a negative, Fred.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Did you call? 137:04:57 LMP Roger, Joe. Figured, if we're going to do this burn in PGNS now, I ought to give you an update on the contingency book pages 32, 33, and 34, because the last time we went through this portion, we were burning it in AGS. 137:05:22 CC Okay,Fred. Stand by.
answer_text: We've been talking about possibly having you do it in AGS. We recommend at this time that you do AGS to PGNS, aline, the 400 plus 3 procedure only. Over. 137:05:44 LMP Okay. 137:06:19 CC And, Aquarius, Houston. 137:06:23 CDR Go ahead, Houston. 137:06:24 CC Roger.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Do you want me to just to aline up the Earth as I did before in the last midcourse? 137:09:46 CC No. We don't want you to do that. Read me your FDAI angles, and let's compare them with what we have down here. 137:09:55 CDR Okay.
answer_text: You're looking at them in the DSKY. I've got roll of 8.47; pitch of about 0.51; and yaw looking at about 3.750. 137:10:18 CC Okay, Jim. Those are very close - I guess all you need to do is trim them up a bit. 137:10:26 CDR I plan to do a final trim - AUTO trim, and then a four-jet translation. 137:10:40 CC Okay, Jim.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Looks good. Do you know whether Jack got any pictures out of window 5? Was it still fogged up?
answer_text: Over. 138:19:09 CDR I don't think so. I think he came right down here, because I think he saw it first in the - in the LM. 138:19:15 CC Okay. Good deal.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Did you get that? Over. 138:45:27 CDR Okay. No, I had 31 and 33, and I got Sigma Libra now, and it'll be 31 and 23 for the set stars. 138:45:34 CC Okay.
answer_text: And your GDC pitch aline, I wasn't sure whether that was - whether you read back 245 or 045. The correct number is 245. Over. 138:45:45 CDR Good show, because I have 045 down. 245. 138:45:48 CC Okay.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Does that sound okay? Over. 139:10:46 CDR Yes. I'll try to hold the attitude we select directly, while you're giving us the coarse aline attitude.
answer_text: We're not too sure what - what's the best attitude. I'm going to ask Jack again if 115 is sufficient for him. 139:11:02 CC Okay. You can take some time figuring out the best attitude, and then you won't have to hold it all the way from now until then, if you just get back to it. 139:12:58 CDR Houston, Jack would like to know what constellations are in his sextant, or scanning telescope, field of view at an attitude of about 105 pitch, zero roll, zero yaw.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Can you give that to us? 139:13:15 CC Okay. We'll sure give it a go. As I said, we - We have some stars.
answer_text: They're not - They're not centered with the shaft and trunnion zero. Let us take a quick look at 105 pitch, shaft and trunnion zero, and see if we can get you an answer. 139:13:52 CC Aquarius, Houston. 139:13:55 CDR Go Houston. 139:13:56 CC Roger. These - None of these stars will be exactly centered, but, at a pitch attitude of 115, we had computed that Vega, Altair, Rasalhague, and Deneb would all be in the telescope field of view, and the first three were also in view at the 91-degree pitch, so he should be able to see one or more of those four stars.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Why don't you give us the shaft and trun- nion for - say, Altair at 115, and I'll go up there, and I'll see if he can pick it up. 139:14:52 CC Okay. Real fine. At 115 degrees of pitch, Altair, shaft 274, trunnion 22.2.
answer_text: Over. 139:15:08 CDR Roger. Shaft is 274, trunnion 22.2. 139:15:11 CC That's affirm. 139:15:44 CC Aquarius, Houston. 139:15:47 CDR Go ahead, Joe. 139:15:48 CC Okay, Jim. In the LM, there we have - We show battery 3 only drawing about an amp, and we think it's probably time to get it off the line; battery 3 to OFF/RESET.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Over. 139:16:10 CDR Battery 3 is OFF/RESET. 139:16:12 CC Okay. 139:16:19 CDR Just how's our power consumption, Houston, just out of curiosity? 139:16:25 CC I'll verify it, Jim. I'm sure it's okay. 139:16:47 CC Okay, Aquarius; Houston. With the present amount of power you've got in the LM, which is over 500 amp-hours, and the rate you're using them, we figure you've got almost 12 hours of power left. 1 139:17:04 CDR Twelve hours, huh?
answer_text: We could reenter with it. 139:17:06 CC That's affirm. 139:17:15 CC That's enough for two touch-and-goes and a full stop, Jim. 139:17:24 CDR That's right, Joe; if you could dig a crater like Cone Crater, I could might hit it. 139:17:30 CC (Laughter) Okay. 139:17:33 CDR Jack reports that he thinks he can see Altair. 139:17:36 CC Very good. 139:17:40 CDR He says, he thinks he can see Altair. 139:17:44 CC Okay. I'll take back the "very," but I'll leave the "good." 139:21:22 CDR Houston, Aquarius. 139:21:25 CC Aquarius, Houston. Go. 139:21:30 CDR I ran back there to take a look and see what I could see in the - in the scanning telescope.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Can you read them? 140:21:36 CC Negative. Don't read Odyssey yet; has he got his intercom panel configured? 140:21:41 CDR I'll doublecheck. They're hearing you. 140:21:49 CC Okay.
answer_text: Good deal. I don't hear them, yet. 140:22:01 CDR Are you ready for an E-MEMORY dump, VERB 74? 140:22:07 CC Stand by for just 1 minute, Jim. 140:22:42 CDR We've got a lot of things to do, Houston. 140:22:45 CC I know it. Okay, Aquarius; Houston.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Can you give me any stars that I might try here? 140:49:28 CC That's affirmative. Vega and Altair should be good. Vega is 36, Altair is 40. 140:49:36 CMP Okay.
answer_text: We'll give that a try. 140:49:38 CC Okay. And you might look for them in the tele- scope if they're not in the sextant right off. They should be close to the crosshairs. 140:49:45 CMP Okay.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: What was the other? 141:02:13 CMP 42. 141:02:15 CC Got it. Thank you. 141:02:22 CDR Okay, Houston; Aquarius. I am at the LM SEP attitude and I'm planning on bailing out. 141:02:32 CC Okay.
answer_text: I can't think of a better idea, Jim. 141:02:36 CDR I'll go to AGS ATT HOLD, if you want me to. 141:02:40 CC We recommend that, Jim. 141:02:54 CC Okay, Aquarius; Houston. In AGS ATT HOLD, we recommend WIDE DEADBAND. Over. 141:03:01 CDR I'm in the AGS DEADBAND. 141:03:04 CC Roger. 141:03:35 CC Aquarius, Houston.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: Do you want me to go ahead and put the BMAG ON with the TEMP light still ON? 141:22:50 CC That's affirm. We can go ahead and you'll have a good stable rate. 141:22:55 CMP All right. Let's do it. 141:26:38 CMP Okay, Houston.
answer_text: We'll punch off at l4l plus 30. 141:26:43 CC Okay, Jack. We copy and we concur. 141:28:21 CMP Okay, Houston. Do we have a GO for PYR0 ARM? 141:28:34 CC Odyssey, Houston.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: How does the LM look? Are you still tracking it? 142:01:17 CC All I've heard was that it's - that the cabin was holding pressure. I haven't heard anything more.
answer_text: And, Odyssey, we're ready for you to warm up the BMAG number 2's at your discretion and we're curious whether the Moon check attitude is good. Over. 142:01:43 CMP Yes, Joe, it's coming down. I got just about 45 degrees now and it's coming on down. 142:01:50 CC Roger that. 142:06:12 CC Odyssey, Houston.

title: AS13_TEC
question_text: How did the EMS check go, Jack? 142:18:36 CMP EMS checked out okay - - 142:18:39 CC Good deal. 142:18:40 CMP - - been initialized and sitting on ENTRY. 142:18:42 CC Roger. 142:20:21 CMP Okay, Joe. Are you watching - you and FIDO taking a look at our NOUN 60 here? 142:20:26 CC That's affirmative. Hold it just a second; we are looking at 6.13 and 4.80.
answer_text: I'll get a check on that. 142:20:37 CMP Okay. That's not too many g's. 142:20:41 CC Jack, FIDO says that's okay. 142:20:45 CMP Okay. 142:21:21 CC Jack, Houston. Your NOUN 63 looks good to us also. 142:21:25 CMP Okay. 142:22:08 CMP Joe, how far out do ycu show us now? 142:22:12 CC Oh, on our plotboard up here, we can't hardly see how far out you are. 142:22:19 CMP Okay. 142:22:28 CMP I know all of us here want to thank all you guys down there for the very fine job you did. 142:22:36 CDR That's affirm, Joe. 142:22:38 CC I'll tell you - We all had a good time doing it. 142:22:56 CC Okay, Odyssey; Houston.
